TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Acting Prime Minister. I refer him to his previous statements that there is a massive inequity in the tax system and that the tax system is often a rip-off for the wealthy. Does the Acting Prime Minister still support the imposition of a wealth tax, and would a wealth tax make our society more equitable?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —-If I were asked to say what I believed about tax, I would say that, above all else, I believe that a taxation system should be fair. I would want to contrast the taxation system with the system we inherited in 1983, which had become quite scandalous, not so much because of what it did but because of what it failed to do, not so much because of the taxes that were collected but because of the failure to collect tax from those who had the greatest capacity to pay it.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member does not really have a great deal of credibility when it comes to the area of taxation. He speaks within the context of a Party which is built on privilege, which remains committed to privilege, and which certainly has never sought fairness or equity in relation to the taxation system. —-I conclude my remarks by saying that, as far as the Government is concerned, it is well known that we have taken a number of steps to improve the equity of the taxation system. TALK.START.PARA: —-I direct my question to the Acting Treasurer. In light of recent surveys of business conditions and other economic indicators, can the Minister inform the House whether the Budget forecasts for a pick-up in economic activity are on track?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In response to the honourable member for Scullin's question, I can say to the House that there is no reason to believe at all that the Budget forecasts are not on track. In the two months since that time, there has been all sorts of evidence that the recovery which was forecast in the Budget is taking place and is likely to take place in broadly the way in which it was described in the Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: The Budget forecast for GDP was that during this year we would have growth of 3 3/4 per cent compared with a decline of 2.4 per cent in 1990-91--a very dramatic turnaround--and with that recovery we would get employment growth in the second half of the year with something like 100,000 jobs. Of course, various factors are driving that growth. They include an expected increase in private consumption because of particularly increasing real disposal incomes, the improvement in the rebuilding of stocks as a result of the substantial run-down in non-farm stocks over the last couple of years--they are probably at a point where they would need to be rebuilt--and a substantial improvement in dwelling investment and also in exports.

As I say, the indicators since the Budget are that there is every reason to believe that those forecasts will be fulfilled. Various surveys have shown that there is expectation by industry of recovery in the course of this year. Recently the National Australia Bank quarterly survey for the September quarter showed less adverse business conditions in that quarter and significantly less adverse or positive expectations for the December quarter, and expectations for the next 12 months indicating strong growth in profitability, output and capital expenditure. The CAI-Westpac survey of industrial trends said that the decline in manufacturing activity had bottomed out in the September quarter, with respondents anticipating a modest recovery.

The Dun and Bradstreet business expectation survey released last Thursday shows the third successive quarterly improvement in business expectations, with expectations for the December quarter showing improvements in sales, profits and new orders, together with a smaller run-down on inventories and less labour shedding. Yesterday, the MTIA survey of the metal industry showed that over the next 12 months there will be a very substantial increase in the proportion of respondents who expect increases in forward orders, sales, exports, production activity, investment and employment. Today the Westpac leading index was released, which shows that index at its highest level since February of 1990. All of these surveys that have been around for the last month or so certainly give credence to the view that we are in the course of a recovery during this year.

Of course, the evidence is starting to come out in the statistics themselves. Building approvals in the last two quarters have been rising and are now up by 5.4 per cent on last year. Housing finance rose by 8 per cent in July and is now 36 per cent above last year. Retail trade figures for August rose by 1.4 per cent, giving the third strong rise in the last four months.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Look at those behind you.
—-I know the other side is not interested.
—-What about the unemployment?
—-Important to honourable members on this side--
—-You have over 10 per cent unemployed.
—-I warn the member for Corinella.

—-There is clear evidence that the decline in employment has now virtually bottomed out. We have had ups and downs in the last three or four months, but the level of employment--the number of people employed--in Australia in September was the same as it was in June, so we have virtually had that bottoming out which was forecast in the Budget and we would expect to see increases later this year. The DEET leading indicator of employment released last week has now risen for four months in a row.

ANSWER.PARA: We are in a position where we can say that the Budget forecasts are on track and that the recovery that was forecast appears likely to take place. Indeed, there is evidence that it is already occurring. But the Government is not simply resting on the Budget and saying that there is nothing else it needs to do. It is looking at every possible action it can take to try to generate more activity within its strategy.

In that respect, as the Prime Minister announced last week, we have instituted a review of business tax to assess its competitiveness against the business tax regimes in other countries, and a review of major projects will be conducted to consider what might be done to get some of those projects up and moving more quickly than would otherwise be the case. A report on the latter matter will come back to Cabinet by the end of this month.

In answer to the honourable member for Scullin, I believe that there is every reason to believe that the Budget forecasts were accurate, that the recovery is taking place and that this Government remains alert to taking every possible action to ensure that it gets higher rates of growth in activity and employment.

ANSWER.PARA: The question I was asked on the issues of foreign ownership went to this: as members of the Opposition well know, there has always been a difference on the question of foreign ownership as it appears under the Broadcasting Act and foreign ownership as it relates to the Foreign Investment Review Board. The fact of the matter is that in the broadcasting area all sections of the broadcasting community are obliged to conform to strict foreign investment rules, with that strict 20 per cent limit, and where they do not, they become the subject of investigation. This will become less the case over the years, but it is still the case now. Whatever might be the barriers to market entry in newspapers, and those are not inconsiderable, newspapers are not a technically limited resource and, therefore, successive governments, including this one, have taken a position on foreign investment in that area which is different from the position that has obtained under the Broadcasting Act. The proof of the pudding is, of course, in the eating. If one goes around the print media in this country, one will find that most of the operations--

—-I ask the Acting Prime Minister to inform the House how much Government funding the Catholic Social Welfare Commission receives and how this Government money is spent. How is its capacity to deal with broader social concerns assisted by Government funding?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —-I think all honourable members will be interested in the answer to the question. The Catholic Social Welfare Commission received funding of $859,000 from the Government in this financial year for its natural family planning secretariat. It makes a significant contribution, as honourable members would know, to the broader social concerns of this country by providing clinical services, which include one-to-one teaching on natural family planning by accredited teachers, as well as the training of health professionals and community education.

ANSWER.PARA: The funding also contributes to the natural family planning secretariat. In fact, it is one of a number of secretariats of community organisations that were discussed by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs. Its unanimous report, You have your moments, which discussed the funding of peak health and community organisations, was published in February of this year. The deputy chair of that Committee is the honourable member for Hawker, and the Committee also includes the honourable member for McEwen, the honourable member for Lyne, the honourable member for Sturt, and, interestingly enough, the honourable member for Franklin. The Committee unanimously recommended continued Commonwealth funding for national secretariats of non-government health, housing and community service organisations on the basis that public education, public debate and community consultation assist the development of appropriate policies and programs, especially where disadvantaged groups are concerned.

Although five members of the Opposition obviously support the funding of community organisations to publicly espouse the interests of the disadvantaged, it would seem that there is some question on the view of the Opposition. I quote from a story from the Australian yesterday:

With the release of its controversial goods and services tax imminent, the federal Opposition is planning a tough pre-emptive campaign against government-funded community interest groups that come out against the tax.

The federal Liberal Party secretariat has compiled a national profile of publicly funded lobby groups which it plans to use if such groups attack the consumption tax while claiming to represent the interests of consumers.

The fact of the matter is that the Catholic Social Welfare Commission, amongst other things, published a report that dealt directly with the issue of the goods and services tax. In that report it argued that the bulk of arguments presented for a goods and services tax did not appear to justify its introduction and that taxation `should be direct and honest, not hidden and devious'.
Opposition members--Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —-Honourable members will be aware that this is laughter by the Liberal Party and the National Party about the state of the National Catholic Social Welfare Commission, about its capacity to produce an intelligent, critical report on the issue of the goods and services tax, and about its fundamental right as an organisation that receives government funding to make use of some related resources it may have to attack a proposal from the Opposition that deals with the issue of the goods and services tax. These people are not prepared to countenance that.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition has a committee which produced a report that says there ought to be public debate and that an organisation which is funded by the Government ought to be able to join in public debate without fear or favour. When an organisation produces a report that the Opposition does not like--it does not like the Australian Council of Social Service--it wants to attack that body. It says to the Catholic Social Welfare Commission, `You had better be worried because you are on a hit list that is going to be dealt with when the appropriate time comes'. It is very interesting that when an organisation contributes to debate--an organisation that is supposed to be about rights and protecting people's capacity to contribute to debate--the threats come out. We hear not only from the secretariat but from the Leader of the National Party that clearly it would be subject to `Treasury model tax A, B, and C, and that many of the publicly funded lobby groups would attack it as well'. They say, `We have factored all this in'--that is, organisations that get into the business of debating this issue do so at their risk.

This question of a goods and services tax is a controversial issue. One would expect the community sector to have views about that and to want to express those views, and to produce publications and research reports that relate to that issue. The National Catholic Social Welfare Commission has a right to expect that its views will be respected and that it will not appear on some hit list to be knocked off by an Opposition that does not believe in free speech.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the aviation component of the honourable member's question--the figures were released here yesterday--is this: 4.7 million passengers were carried by the airlines during the September quarter. That represents an 18 per cent increase over the previous record set in our bicentennial year in 1988; 5.1 billion revenue passenger kilometres were flown, an increase of 30 per cent on the previous record; 6.4 billion available seat kilometres were performed, which is an increase of 34 per cent on the previous record. One can guess from all of this the very significant impact on the tourism industry which comes from the contribution made by aviation. Of course, in various prospects circulating as to what the Government might do about it, we come to the issue of the attitude in this community to the significance of that tourism industry. We find that the Opposition tourism spokesman was discussing this quite recently--over the weekend--at a tourism forum.

Of course, that forum had to live down the comments of his leader in July in which he said he equated tourism with the black economy. I suppose, on the basis of that particular logic, we have had the tourism spokesman announce the level of the goods and services tax at 12 1/2 per cent. I suppose we assume that it will fall between 10 and 15 per cent, so we will settle on that 12 1/2 per cent level. He went on to say--

—-My question is also addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I ask him: having finally won his long fought battle with the Luddites in his Party over the introduction of pay TV, when will the really hard decisions be made on network rules, Australian content rules, cross-media ownership and tendering procedures? In the Government's reaching these decisions, will we witness, as we have over Fairfax, the twists and turns that have characterised this Government as it manipulates the rules to favour its media mates over others?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Until the honourable member got to the end, that was quite a good question.

—-Could I make the point to the honourable member for Menzies that the material towards the end of the question did not assist the question. In fact, it would be out of order. However, the substance of the question still stands.

—-That gives me an opportunity to go through what has been an excellent decision by the Government in terms of both the entertainment of the public and the prospect for jobs in this community, because there is no question at all. There are industries in this country which can support the development of a pay TV operation by providing the infrastructure--the dishes, the decoders and the rest--and also, of course, by developing Australian products for a pay TV operation. So we do look upon this as a measure which will materially contribute in the employment area as well as address what are now technical realities in the services which might be provided.

ANSWER.PARA: If the Opposition member who asked this question had read my press release, he would have seen these things: firstly, the lifting of the ban takes place in October next year, which brings it into line with the availability of the service from the new Aussat satellites, which should be up by then and being effectively calibrated for the purpose. So we have until that date to effectively establish the regime which will regulate the development of pay TV.

Nevertheless, Cabinet foreshadowed certain attitudes to it. The first was in the area of cross-media rules. Cabinet decided firmly--I might say on my recommendation--that nobody who currently owned television stations in this country would be permitted to have any more than 25 per cent of a pay TV consortium. Of course, the question arises: what if there are two or three television stations in operation together in the one consortium, thereby being capable of taking their ownership well over 50 per cent? That was left as an unsettled question. It is a matter which we will go through in the process of the review of the general regulations. But my disposition is that we would not permit such a situation to take place.

In the area of foreign ownership it was decided that there should be foreign ownership restrictions. The exact level of foreign ownership restrictions was not set. That will also await further regulatory study. I will go into the regulatory study in a minute, but I will try to pick up all the points the honourable member raised.

The honourable member also raised the issue of Australian content. As he would be aware, under the current Broadcasting Act, the levels of Australian content are not established by legislation; they are established in the first instance by government disposition. The Government indicates to the Broadcasting Tribunal that it thinks the operators of free-to-air television should be obliged to provide a substantial level of Australian content. On the basis of consultation, it sets particular limits. On the whole, those limits have been increasing in favour of Australian produced product. We envisage something similar applying in the pay TV area. A broadcasting authority would make some determination about what the appropriate levels of Australian content ought to be.

As I said, we have 12 months to finalise all of this, but the process by which it gets finalised is intimately bound up with future discussion on the broadcasting services Bill which will make wholesale changes to the way in which broadcasting services are regulated in this country, and which the Government intends to bring forward for public consideration prior to Christmas and then for detailed final legislative processes after Christmas, with the intention of having it in place by the middle of next year--in ample time.

In relation to the process of finalising who should hold the national licence--as there would be one national licence in operation--the Government envisages a tender process. The criteria that would be established in the tender process would go to a whole series of things such as intentions in relation to industry support, and there would be a price in that tender process. The tender process would be conducted, I presume, in those circumstances, by my Department.

There is another area of pay TV which was also opened up--delivery across the country by systems effectively other than a national system, utilising the satellite. That would be done, for example, by broadening the base of the MDS system, which currently supports activities of VAS hotels, and permitting niche operations into people's households. That would be done, effectively, by establishing conditions for a class licence. The class licence also will appear in the Broadcasting Act.

The intention here is not to protect any particular set of what the honourable member defines as `media mates'; it is obvious from the decisions that we have already taken that, when implemented, those decisions will broaden the base of ownership of a particular media outlet in this community. In addition, the Cabinet decided in principle that it would have no objection to the ABC and SBS participating in pay TV opportunities, though, again, that would be something that would have to be worked through in consultation with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This is a long answer.

—-If those opposite ask lengthy and detailed questions they will cop lengthy and detailed answers. —-Can the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services inform the House whether claims made on the ABC's Four Corners program are valid with regard to the serious health concerns associated with certain types of breast implants? What action has the Government taken on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the honourable member for Cowan for her very important question which, contrary to what it may seem to the Opposition, is of concern to many people on this side of the House and in the community. There have been concerns about silicone breast implants in Canada, the United States and Australia. These have prompted action by the respective governments to obtain information to justify the quality and the safety of these devices. The Therapeutic Goods Administration wrote to all sponsors and manufacturers of breast implants in July this year seeking such justification by 30 November this year. I am quite happy to table that letter, which may be of interest to honourable members.

ANSWER.PARA: Since almost all breast implants are imported from the United States, this action is being taken very much in conjunction and cooperation with the US Food and Drug Administration. As in the United States, it is likely that some companies will withdraw their products from the market or be required to withdraw their products because of failure to submit the required information. The polyurethane-coated implant which was the subject of much concern in last night's program was withdrawn from Australia and, indeed, worldwide by that company in April this year.

In Australia we have exempted saline-filled prostheses from this review of safety and quality. We will be pushing our manufacturers to use those water-based fillings. I make the point that it is the responsibility of the medical profession to ensure that patients are fully informed about the risks associated with breast implants. For that matter, people should be much better informed about the risks associated with or the side effects of other devices and drugs.

The Government set up a therapeutic device problem reporting scheme to provide an avenue to alert the regulatory authorities, such as the Therapeutic Goods Administration, about problems patients might be experiencing with medical devices. That was highlighted on the ABC's Investigators program on 8 October. People who experience anything they might perceive to be a problem with a medical device, including such things as surgical implants, should call the reporting scheme hotline that is now available. The number is available through press release and in other forms.

Therapeutic devices that are used in Australia apply to both sexes but many of them also apply particularly to the health needs of women. In that regard, the Government considers the role of women in the therapeutic devices area to be very important. That is why we have increased the representation of women on those therapeutic device evaluation committees from one only 12 months ago to four out of the eight now. It is a very important area of health care. We rely more and more upon the use of drugs and therapeutic devices for our health and well-being and upon processes such as this but, very importantly, upon accurate reporting and information to patients about problems--

TALK.START.PARA: —-He is almost as boring as you, Brian.
—-The honourable member for Lowe!
—-The honourable member for Lowe should not interject too much. If the honourable member for Lowe had the decency to have his own health policy, this country might be better informed.
—-The Minister should not be provoked by the honourable member for Lowe's interjection.
—-Are you finished?
—-Order! The member for Gilmore!

—-I am quite happy to finish, Mr Acting Speaker. The point is that it is of great concern to many people in the community, particularly women who are the subject of or who choose to undergo surgery such as breast implants, that they receive not only the best products but also the best information. It would certainly help the Government, the women and the health of the community generally if these problems were better reported and acknowledged through the community and medical processes.

—-I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. He will be aware that the Government's own drought task force reported its findings to the Government in May 1990. Why is it that 18 months after the drought task force reported, the Government still has no definition of `extreme drought' or `hardship'? Is he aware that this means that there are farm families who want to stay on their farms, have no borrowing capacity or income and yet do not qualify for any Government assistance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My understanding is that the report itself was commissioned in 1989 but was not presented until 1990.
—-May 1990. I thought the honourable member said 1989. The point is that the Government--
—-It is a bit like your tax policy.

—-Do Opposition members want to hear the answer to the question, which is a serious question? It is no laughing matter, as is apparent to anyone who happened to be up in the areas that are affected by the drought, as I have been over the last couple of weeks. We will have the opportunity in the matter of public importance at the conclusion of Question Time to go in more detail into those issues; but I think some important points need to be stated now.

ANSWER.PARA: First of all, whilst there were a number of recommendations coming from that 1990 report, there was general acceptance by the Commonwealth and the State governments that we should not treat drought as a separate circumstance of financial hardship, that it should be incorporated, like all matters contributing to financial hardship, largely under one effective mechanism. That is what we have done by developing the rural adjustment scheme and by pumping significant financial reserves into that scheme. This year it is an additional $100m, and it is currently being reviewed this month, with me to take a submission to Cabinet at the end of this month as to the adequacy of funds.

The point that needs to be understood is that the reason why that report said that drought should not be treated separately is that there are many factors that impact upon a farmer's financial difficulty. If honourable members are prepared to look at the comparisons--and I will go into this in some detail later--between the present drought and the one in 1982-83, which was much more widespread than the drought now, they will see that the impact on rural communities is almost about as severe today. Why? Fundamentally it is because of the dramatic fall in commodity prices.

What we are trying to do is to bring some order and sense into a system whereby people, whatever the reason for their financial hardship, can get support. It also ought to be understood that the rural adjustment scheme is a scheme to ensure adjustment, to provide carry-on finance for people to get through the difficult time, whether it is drought or whatever, and to ensure that they have the ability, amongst other things, to use carry-on finance.

I happen to believe that that distinction ought to be maintained. If there are to be methods of providing income support or household support, I happen to believe that that support should be appropriately allocated through the Department of Social Security provisions. That is also a matter on which I am having discussions with my colleague the Minister for Social Security in the context of the review that is currently taking place.

So my answer to the honourable member's question is this: I am fully aware of the impact of the drought. I have argued very strongly about the need for the Government to take action. That action will be taken, but it will not just be through the rural adjustment scheme, which we have to negotiate with the States and about which I will be meeting with them next week; we will be looking to take it also through mechanisms that currently exist.

We will be prepared to look after farm families; we will not be prepared to condone the sorts of schemes that existed in the past whereby particular drought assistance led to rorting. Examples were alluded to--I will finish on this point--by the drought review body whereby regions in Queensland were declared drought needy 70 per cent of the time between 1964 and 1989. That is the sort of thing that used to go on under a National Party rorted system that really did not make allocations based on need, that did not really understand that financial hardship could be caused by mechanisms other than drought, and that tried to lump into Commonwealth funds based on analysis and definition that States took without any reference to the Commonwealth. We are going to clean that up. We are going to have an effective drought policy. But, most importantly, we are going to have an effective assistance policy for those farm families that are in financial difficulties.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories. What action has the Federal Government taken to provide a coordinated framework to assist the tourism industry and improve its international competitiveness?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Simmons The Hon D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the honourable member for Leichhardt for his question and, indeed, his very obvious interest in the tourism industry, as he represents one of the great tourism regions within Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: A number of honourable members in this House would be aware of a series of nationwide consultations in which I am currently involved to develop a national tourism strategy. I have already met with a number of tourism representatives, members of the general public and industry organisations in a range of public meetings in the six States and the Territories. Honourable members in this House and those others who understand the nature of the tourism industry would know that it is an industry that is extremely diverse--ranging from areas such as accommodation and attractions to transport, restaurants and tour operations. The purpose of this strategy is to try to develop a coordinated approach so that ultimately there is a shared commitment between government and the industry as to the future directions of the industry. This is important if we are likely to achieve the targets set for the year 2000; that is, six million inbound visitors.

While we undoubtedly have the best tourism product in the world, that alone is certainly not enough to secure the sorts of numbers that we are currently talking about in terms of the development of this strategy. We need to ensure that we have an appropriate infrastructure in place; we need to maintain our present excellent international promotion effort through the Australian Tourist Commission; and, most importantly, we need to remain price competitive.
During consultations serious concerns have been expressed to me by industry representatives of the likely impact of a goods and services tax on the very competitive position of the tourism industry.
Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-The usual line trotted out by honourable members opposite is that every other major tourist country in the world has a GST or a VAT, so why not Australia? I think we should ask that question in the reverse: why should we not continue to have a special internationally competitive position that makes us continue to be a very attractive international tourist destination? Unlike the United Kingdom and North America, Australia is a long haul destination and when we are talking about international attractiveness for Australia's inbound markets, as such we must understand that price sensitivity is very important.

ANSWER.PARA: I must admit that I was a little disappointed with my colleague the honourable member for Fadden, the shadow Minister for tourism and aviation, during the discussion last week of a matter of public importance dealing with the impact of taxation and the level of competitiveness in this industry.I thought he would have taken the opportunity during that debate to explain how the tourism industry would be affected by a GST. But no, not one single word was uttered during that debate about the GST and its impact on the industry.

As the Minister for Transport and Communications mentioned this afternoon, at the Australian Tourist Industry Association conference in Brisbane last Friday the honourable member for Fadden was specifically addressing, so he told us, the effect of a GST on the tourism industry. But all he could do was hint at certain exemptions for inbound tourists. Again, as the Minister pointed out, important as inbound tourists are to this country, 80 per cent of the tourist market in Australia is domestically based. The Opposition does not seem to understand that. If it is going to exempt inbound tourists from its proposal, I guess that is commendable, but surely it must realise that this market, the Australian market, represents 80 per cent of the total market.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Which side are you on?
—-Order! The honourable member for Flinders!
—-I am on the side of the tourism industry. The last thing I want to do is to encourage further outbound travel from Australia.
—-He wants to put a tax on them.
—-Order! If the honourable member for Flinders continues to interject, I will name him.

—-I want to encourage domestic travel in this country, and so should the Opposition. Every time the Government broaches the subject of a GST, honourable members are accused of scare tactics, even when the matters we raise are quite reasonable and quite rational arguments. A GST is regressive. It will cause prices to increase in an industry that is extraordinarily price sensitive, particularly on the inbound market side.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think it is unreasonable to point out these things. It is perfectly okay, it seems, for the Opposition to go about fallaciously implying that the current wholesale sales tax regime adds 20 to 30 per cent to the cost of the tourism industry. That is an absolute nonsense, and honourable members opposite should know it.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I raise a point of order. Mr Acting Speaker, you have previously asked Ministers to limit the length of their replies. This Minister is now exceeding the time limit that exists by convention. I ask that you ask him to draw his answer to a close.
—-I suggest that the Minister has almost concluded his answer.

—-I am very happy to complete my answer. I point out in relation to this issue of the wholesale sales tax, which is very much the subject of a scare campaign by the Opposition, that inputs to the tourism industry currently attracting a sales tax from only a relatively small part of the industry's overall cost; but under a GST all of it would be added to the cost, whether it is 12 1/2 per cent or 15 per cent, and we await the particular figure. Under the existing sales tax regime, 2 to 4 per cent is added to the total cost in the accommodation sector and about 7 per cent in the transport sector.

ANSWER.PARA: So when the Opposition accuses the Government of scare campaigns, it ought to start looking at some of the things it has been saying in relation to the wholesale sales tax. If I am asked where I stand, I stand for representing the interests of the Australian tourism industry, both in the domestic market and in the important and growing inbound market.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Will the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy acknowledge that the pursuit by the ACTU of wage increases well in excess of current inflation rates would be inflationary and renew upward pressure on interest rates and the dollar? Will the Minister acknowledge that such pressures would be totally devastating to the already depressed rural sector? Will the Minister give an undertaking to his new farm constituency to act in their best interests and resolutely oppose any real increase in wages unless matched by corresponding productivity improvements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I can give that undertaking and have done so to farm meetings around this country over the past four months. If the honourable member was prepared to go back and look at his figures, he would understand that since 1983 there has not been a wage increase in this country in aggregate terms higher than the rate of inflation. In other words, for the first time in the history of this country--
—-But what about productivity?

—-I will come to the question of productivity in a minute; it happens to be my patch, even though it may not be my portfolio. Not only have we produced consistently non-inflationary wages growth in each of the years that this Government has been in power, but also we will continue to secure agreements from the ACTU to that effect. We are the only government in the history of this country that has seen the significance of wages policy.

ANSWER.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition should turn around and listen to this, because the Achilles heel for the Liberal Party is wages policy; it does not have one. That is why in the last drought period, to which I have just referred, honourable members opposite had such high rates of inflation. Their Government was unable to control wages policy, because they had no basis for talking to the trade union movement about achieving it.

Apart from what this Government has been able to achieve through the accord--that is, non-inflationary wages growth in each of the years that it has been in power--over the last three years the wages system has moved significantly, and for the first time in the history of this nation, to linking wage increases to productivity improvements. What do honourable members think the second tier wage negotiation was about?
Dr Hewson interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The Chair extends an extra degree of tolerance to the Leader of the Opposition. However, he ought not to abuse it by continuing to interject as he has during Question Time.

—-The forerunner to that direction was the 4 per cent productivity offset. The next development was the award restructuring. Honourable members need to understand that not only does this country have a wages policy that can contain aggregate outcomes below the inflation rate but also, in the context of the last Budget, including the superannuation component, the ACTU has committed itself to working with the Government to ensure that our wage increases will not detract from our international competitiveness with our trading partners. Not only do we have that commitment in terms of future aggregates, but we also have the dynamism in wages policy now to drive productivity agreements and get them into place.

ANSWER.PARA: Those who laugh ought to look at the understanding that has been reached in relation to the waterfront, for example. That agreement will produce--this is important for the export industries, in particular the farms--productivity savings of the order of 60 per cent. Yet we hear from the other side that such an agreement is not to be welcomed but to be criticised. Where do honourable members opposite really stand on wages policy? Do they say that even if one is prepared to give 60 per cent productivity improvements there should be no wage increase? That is really what their policy stands for. It says, `No matter how much productivity gain you get, you should get no increase'. That is the consistency of the Opposition's position in opposing the outcome on the waterfront.

I am committed, as is this Government, to the view that wage increases have to reflect productivity and productive outcomes in the economy. The challenge to this nation's economy is to become a more productive nation, not just a competitive nation. For the first time in the history of this country, we have a wages policy that can drive it. I think the Australian public is beginning to understand the importance of that. The difficulty is that honourable members on the other side of the House do not understand it. I am going around the country to explain to people in the farm sector where we stand. Quite frankly, it will be the first time they hear it. They will not get it from honourable members opposite, but they will get it from me.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister for Land Transport, whose portfolio includes Australia Post. What would be the outcome of the application of a goods and services tax to Australia Post? Would Australia Post be able to keep its commitment to the Australian community to restrain price increases for standard postal articles below the CPI? Is it intended to introduce such an impost on Australia Post?
—-Mr Acting Speaker, the drafting of that particular question is way out of order, even under the widest interpretation of standing order 145, and it should be ruled out of order.
—-The question as it relates to the Minister's area of public policy is in order; however, it is not for the Minister to answer questions directed specifically to other policies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I appreciate that advice, and I appreciate as well the question that was asked by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, who quite clearly is concerned about the possible impact of a goods and services tax on all those services. People need to be perfectly aware, when the Opposition refers to a wholesale based sales tax, that that tax relates simply to goods which are sold at the wholesale level, so there is no possibility of retail mark-ups being built into that tax structure.

ANSWER.PARA: It contrasts markedly with a proposition that a 15 per cent goods and services tax be put on everything, including all those services which hitherto have not been taxed. The honourable member for Eden-Monaro refers particularly to the impact of such an impost on Australia Post. I have indicated before that, if Australia Post had increased the price of a standard letter in accordance with the CPI since about 1977, the charge for a standard letter in January of next year would be about 70c instead of the 45c which is proposed.

It is also significant that that 45c cost for a standard letter at the beginning of next year, as a result of the 15 per cent consumption tax, would increase to about 52c. So the impost that the Opposition proposes would be responsible, for the first time, for putting the cost of sending a letter from a person to his or her next-door neighbour through the half a dollar limit--to 52c.

It is also interesting that a special provision has been made by Australia Post so that at Christmas time people can send their Christmas cards and communicate with their friends and relatives wherever they happen to be in Australia not for 43c but for 38c. If we were to put a 15 per cent goods and services tax on, for example, the cost of sending Christmas cards, that would take the cost from the present level up to 45c, which would put it ahead of the cost of sending a commercial letter.

There are some other interesting implications of the goods and services tax. The total revenue from services by Australia Post last year was about $1 billion. None of that represented tax. As a result of a 15 per cent goods and services tax being imposed on Australia Post, that would represent--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 145. It relates to the comments being made by the Minister. He clearly is expressing an opinion when he refers to 15 per cent. The Opposition has not released a percentage rate yet. The Minister, talking in specific terms of percentage rates, is only expressing an opinion. I ask you to rule the Minister out of order.
—-There is no point of order as to relevance; however, I would think the Minister has answered the question.
—-Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a further point of order. Could I ask you on what basis you say there is no point of order?
—-There is no point of order. The Minister is answering a question within his portfolio responsibility.

—-Opposition members--especially those on the back benches, most of whom will soon not be here as a result of the stupidity of the goods and services tax--become increasingly distressed and disturbed as the time of judgment draws near. The Australian people will be perfectly aware of the imposition of a goods and services tax. Australia Post, for a start, will become responsible every year for collecting about $150m in tax. The implications of that are quite serious: all those services which in the past have been free of tax will be taxed. Major Australian institutions such as Australia Post will become, in effect, a branch of the Taxation Office. There will be one essential function of Australia Post as far as the Opposition is concerned--as a revenue collecting institution.

ANSWER.PARA: All of the improvements in Australia Post have been brought about as a result of improved efficiencies. There is no doubt that, given the opportunity, Australia Post will be able to serve the Australian people as it has in the past and as it is doing increasingly better. But, as a result of these changes, there is no doubt that the whole structure--the purpose and the composition--of Australia Post would undergo a significant change and $150m would be dragged out of the pockets of Australian taxpayers and channelled through Australia Post straight into government revenue.

DEBATE.TITLE: DISCUSSION OF MATTER OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Lloyd) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The severity of extreme drought in eastern Australia and the Government's failure to adequately assist those suffering its devastation.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LLOYD
TALKER.ROLE: -Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —-Over a vast area of eastern Australia there is now an extreme drought. The rainfall is either the lowest on record, the lowest this century or in the lowest 10 per cent--and this brings up this definition of `extreme drought' as something that happens, say, every 10 to 15 years. We are talking here about extreme doubt, not a prolonged dry period or, as it may have been called at one stage, an ordinary drought.

SPEECH.PARA: Already in Queensland there has been a loss of production, a loss of income of $500m-plus. The area under drought is spreading and the losses are increasing. In New South Wales 55 per cent of the State is now declared to be affected by drought. It is estimated that 20 per cent of farmers in these areas could fail. There has been a dramatic increase in applications to the State adjustment authorities. So far, to my knowledge, the States of New South Wales and Queensland have committed themselves to about $50m and, so far, the Federal Government has committed itself to only $7m.

That extreme drought is bad enough, but it comes on top of the worst rural depression this century. There is the grain trade war between the United States and the European Community. There are the export subsidies of the European Community which interfere with prices for our exports of dairy products, rice, sugar, processed horticultural products and, in certain markets, meat. At present we have the lack of an adequate dumping and countervailing code for this country under this Government. There has been the collapse of the wool market and, according to figures obtained by the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), the seasonal average greasy price of wool up till 27 September 1991 is the lowest in real terms in recorded history of wool sales in Australia, and 8 per cent lower than the price for any year this century.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Say that again.

—-The price this season is the lowest recorded price ever for wool. In addition to that, we have the high cost structure impacting on all farmers in Australia because of the low labour productivity. For example, it costs 2 1/2 times more to slaughter a steer in this country than it does in the United States. We have outrageous rail freights. This Government has inflicted on our farmers the highest real interest rates that any farmers in the world have to suffer.

SPEECH.PARA: The result, according to the September agricultural and resource quarterly report of the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, is that net farm incomes for 1991-92 will be the lowest on record at $2,600. That is 24 per cent down on last year, which in itself was 35 per cent down on the previous year. Remember that those calculations were made basically in July-August and, according to the ABARE, did not include any consideration for the continuation of the drought. So the real figures are worse than that and are dramatically declining.

In addition, according to a separate article, in 1990-91 the debt servicing ratio for 25 per cent of broad acre farmers in this country--the wheat, sheep and beef people--is now 87 per cent; that is, interest payments take up 87 per cent of their gross cash income. Once again, that was for last year, without any calculation for the drought this year.

In total, it is a devastating situation. The dimension is incomprehensible to people who are not from the land and who have not visited those areas extensively. It is incomprehensible to other people in Australia. It means that even the most prudent of farmers with the best drought strategy--and all farmers in rural areas do their best with regard to drought strategy management--cannot manage the situation. It is an extreme drought on top of a rural depression, and the one form of self-help that was there for farmers over the years, an adequate income equalisation deposit scheme, was ruined by this Government. So the Government cannot say to any of the farmers of Australia that they did not do enough to be prudent in relation to this drought situation. Like the drought, the impact is extreme.

For many grain growers in northern New South Wales and the Darling Downs of Queensland there will be virtually no harvest whatsoever. For sheep people, wool production is down 50 per cent and most of it is very poor quality; it is tender. Sheep are dying in their thousands in western New South Wales and western Queensland. Fodder is scarce and too expensive because, as is obvious from the figures I have been quoting, there is no cost benefit in providing fodder for them.

As to cattle, there has been a premature slaughter of significant magnitude, which in itself is tragic because that is one of the few agricultural markets that gives indications that it will strengthen next year. It has implications beyond those individual farmers and beyond the present situation; it impacts on the total national herd in the future. One of the great achievements of the coalition Government's assistance during the 1982 extreme drought was that the national herd was maintained and, with it, the ability to produce export income as well as individual income for those farmers.

Land prices have collapsed. Any talk about the value of a rural property is meaningless in those drought areas. Feral and wild animals are invading what crops and forage there is. Goats, pigs, rabbits, kangaroos and emus in their thousands are invading these properties. People are leaving their farms. The cost of educating children is beyond their ability in those areas. For the sake of their children, some are leaving their properties and moving closer in. The Austudy criteria--even the new criteria introduced by this Government--are useless. Basically, those farmers cannot qualify for Austudy. Welfare is equally impossible to achieve at this time. In spite of the Government saying that it is going to fix it--and we heard again today from the Minister that he is going to fix it--it still has not been fixed 12 months after the rural depression started and we are months into the drought. These people are not able to pay for groceries on their table; they have no effective cash income.

The Minister has promised and promised, but still nothing has been done. Town and community life has been destroyed in many of these areas, whether it is the town businesses, those servicing the rural sector, community life, sporting clubs or whatever. The whole structure of a vast area of rural and regional Australia is now at risk. The people affected have understandable resentment and despair against this Government. They believe --and I agree with them--that they played more than their part over the years in providing exports, in far better than average productivity for this country and in creating national wealth, in which everybody has shared. Yet now in their hour of need, in their period of greatest trouble, they have been deserted by this Government. They ask: does the Government really want a rural sector? Does the Government really want family farms and country towns? So far they have not received any positive reply.

With this extreme drought the Government has done nothing since it removed the ordinary drought arrangements from the natural disaster system in July 1989. Interestingly, when it removed drought from the system, it did nothing to lower the State threshold payments for all natural disasters, so there has been some sneaky work by this Government with the other natural disasters as well. This task force, which according to the rural representatives was stacked by anti-rural people, bought some time for the Government. In its interim report, the task force recommended against ordinary drought--that is, the prolonged dry period, say, every three years or so--being considered a natural disaster. It wanted to look at extreme drought, which is the situation of drought every 10 to 15 years.

The final report of the task force was in May 1990 and the only thing that this Government has accepted out of that May 1990 report is that no drought, not even extreme drought, is to be included in the natural disaster arrangements. The Government has ignored every other recommendation; and some in the rural sector say that they were not the best of recommendations from their point of view.

Nothing has been done to restore tax incentives as was recommended. There is no rural adjustment scheme assistance under part D. So far the Government has provided New South Wales $4.352m and Queensland $2.176m through part B of the rural adjustment scheme. I want to make the point to the Minister, in case he starts talking about the extra $100m for rural adjustment, that that was determined long before the drought was an issue. That was there because of the rural depression and has nothing to do with this drought.

TALK.START.PARA: —-What about what happened under you?

—-If the Minister wants to argue about what the Government has done, he cannot use that argument. If he wants to argue about what it is going to do, everybody has been hearing for months what the Government has been going to do--and nothing has been done.

Labor removed what incentives there were for farmers to be prepared--the tax incentives for fodder conservation and water conservation. The drought task force recommended 18 months ago that they should be restored--and nothing has been done.

The coalition calls on the Government to act--to stop talking, to stop promising, and to stop saying that it is going to fix it. It should get on with it. It should either settle for extreme drought within the natural disaster arrangements, as the farmer organisations and the States prefer, or do something worth while through the rural adjustment scheme. If the Government does that, to be honest it should reduce the State threshold for the other natural disasters. The Government has to fix Austudy also. It has promised that. It has to bring in a better IED scheme. It has to reduce interest rates. Finally, if it really wants to do something about the cost structure in rural and regional Australia, it will bring in a goods and services tax so that transport costs can be reduced for these people.

There is no question that in the regions that I have referred to--southern Queensland and northern New South Wales--drought is a significant contributor to it.

If one looks at the maps and makes a comparison between the rainfall deficiency at the end of the 1982-83 El Nino effect and that for August 1991, one sees that the former was far more extensive than the latter. In 1982-83 the deficiency was so severe that it was the lowest on record over all of Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland, except for the northern coast of New South Wales and a small area of south-east Queensland. Large areas of South Australia and the Northern Territory also experienced record deficiencies. In contrast, the dry conditions of June to August 1991 were restricted to the eastern and southern areas of Queensland and northern New South Wales. Much of Victoria and South Australia has experienced rainfall significantly above the average.

It is important to set that point against the problems that still beset rural Australia in the current circumstances. Again, if we take the comparisons between the two periods, we see that the net value of production declined by 97 per cent in the 1982-83 drought and by 94 per cent in the current circumstances. Prices received by farmers went up by 4 per cent in the earlier period, whereas they have gone down by 18 per cent in the current circumstances and, interestingly, prices paid--this is an important point--went up by 23 per cent in 1982-83 but only by 3.4 per cent currently. In other words, regardless of comparisons of the severity of drought in the land mass of this country, the fall in the real net value of farm production is roughly the same.

It is for that reason that we as a government believe that whatever the causes of financial hardship--whether they be drought, commodity prices, floods or whatever--people ought to be able to access a scheme that gives support and the ability to carry on. We do not believe that we should separate drought and say that it is the major cause of difficulties on the land; it is not.

What we sensibly have to do in policy terms is to recognise that, because we are exposed to international market places and rortings and price subsidies, because we are exposed to climatic conditions, and because we are exposed to a whole range of issues that can impact upon the land, severe hardship is the test. It is not a question of whether drought is causing it or otherwise. That is why we have moved to the incorporation of drought, and the risk management that should be associated with that into the RAS, to ensure that what we are addressing is hardship generally.

I will come to the question of severe hardship because that is where I believe the scheme needs some adjustment, not just because of drought. The reality is that the RAS is needs based. And it ought to be, because people who are most suffering financial hardship ought to be the basis and the target for most attention. The RAS encourages self-help, it encourages risk management, it addresses issues which are beyond the producer's control--those I have mentioned--and it is an adjustment mechanism, not fundamentally a compensation mechanism. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-For many in our coastal areas happiness is the forecast of fine, clear and sunny weekend weather. However, as last weekend's Sydney Sun-Herald pointed out, it is an unfortunate fact that this sun-seeking enjoyment is inevitably someone else's agony. That agony is epitomised in the present extreme drought conditions in parts of New South Wales and Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has said, more than half of New South Wales is officially declared drought stricken, while large parts of southern and central Queensland are arguably in the most severe drought conditions since the 1890s. However, this dry spell is adding another catastrophic dimension to an already struggling rural sector in which powder-dry topsoil is being blown away, turning much of our arable land into hard-baked, bleached, unproductive and irreversible moonscape.

No-one would argue that drought is one of those risk factors that Australian farmers will face from time to time. However, what we have today is a drought of great severity, following hard on the heels of a number of factors: a rural commodity downturn of unparalleled scope and degree, deep domestic recessionary economic conditions, unemployment now in excess of 10 per cent, and a Federal Government--despite what the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), who is at the table, says--that is strong on rhetoric but light on substance when it comes to an empathy for our rural communities and their economic and physical ills.
Arguably, the cumulative impact of this drought is so profound that more than one in

10 of the farming community as we know it today may be forced off the land in the next two or three years. We have in prospect a slump in rural incomes of about 60 per cent over that period of time. This cannot continue without doing permanent damage to the rural sector and the economy as a whole.

I agree with the recent comments by my coalition colleague the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) that this drought could push the economy into a depression unless urgent policy remedial measures are taken. Regrettably, some in this place still remain seemingly oblivious to the extent of the destruction of one of our greatest national assets on which our economic well-being relies in very large part. I would simply like to say to those members: let there be no doubt that we have a national disaster on our hands, not only in terms of its geographic spread but also at the individual family farm level and in terms of the many millions of dollars likely to be lost to our export revenue. We need to avoid blinkered vision that the problem is a minor cyclical one and should realise the extent of its potential to threaten our social fabric and to further degrade our national economic performance.

I turn to my home State of Queensland and economic performance. In some parts of that State the drought began with poor seasonal rainfall in the middle of last year. The situation became critical this year after the normally wet months of January and February failed to yield their usual rainfall. Very little rain has fallen since in the south-eastern and central regions. In terms of wheat production, last season Queensland harvested around two million tonnes. At the end of this season, output is expected to be about 400,000 tonnes. In other words, Queensland's 5,000 wheat farmers must resign themselves to a 75 per cent reduction in their annual output, which usually provides around 10 per cent of the 13 to 15 million tonnes of wheat that this country exports each year.

I turn to sugarcane. At the end of November, Queensland growers will harvest about two-thirds of last year's quota of 3.6 million tonnes of sugar. That represents a loss of $200m State-wide in export earnings.

In the case of the Queensland beef industry, which nets about $1.4 billion a year, the full impact is not yet clear. However, in many places feed supplies are non-existent, very low or too expensive because of short supply. Many cattlemen are saying that they can no longer guarantee the usual quotas that they supply interstate.

In the case of the dairy industry, the State's annual 630 million litres of milk, or 10 per cent of the national output, will be seriously affected. At best, many dairy farmers are breaking even; at worst, they are now borrowing heavily to meet increasing feed bill demands.

In my area of the Darling Downs, even easier to grow substitute crops such as chickpeas for the Indian and Bangladesh markets have also failed. The big worry has to be that we may lose the Japanese market for prime hard wheat to an overseas competitor. What is in prospect is the invidious situation of our having to consider imports from the United States to sell to Japan in order to retain the market share.

I turn now to the personal impact. I draw to the House's attention the situation of a wheat farmer in my area--I will call him Mr C--who in mid-June of this year planted 40 hectares of wheat on his 260-hectare property. There has not been a drop of rain since and, with the crop having grown to only 20 centimetres and little chance of it developing further even if rain comes soon, it is now being devoured by dairy cattle on agistment from Toowoomba and elsewhere. If this wheat crop had succeeded, it would have realised around $40,000. Mr C also planted 40 hectares of barley a month or so before his wheat plantings. This has no chance of maturing but has grown high enough to be cut and baled for fodder. As Mr C has said:

I have had the substantial cost of the seed and the planting. What I get for the crop as fodder does not even cover my costs. On top of that, I don't know when I'll be paid for the fodder I've sold because most are broke. I don't know where the money is going to come from for my next planting.

The General President of the Queensland Graingrowers Association, Mr Ian McFarlane, has echoed this frustration; he pointed out that last year we could not get a worthwhile price because of a combination of oversupply and the US and European subsidies. Whereas this year the price is good, there will not be enough grain to meet demand and only a few farmers will make any money. In fact, at the recent ABARE rural outlook conference in Toowoomba, the point was made that around 40 per cent of broad acre farmers are likely to have negative farm incomes this financial year and that almost half of farm families had taxable incomes, including off-farm incomes, of less than $10,000 last financial year--with prospects, of course, worsening.

Furthermore, at a recent Country Women's Association meeting on the Darling Downs, delegates made the following points: many children would not return to city schools after Christmas and enrolments at the Charleville School of the Air might increase up to 50 per cent; such self-education at home would place further demands on country women already struggling to save their properties; and women in regional areas have little access to social services. A case was cited where one woman with two small children had been feeding her family boiled rice for a week and did not know what they would eat next.

Many delegates expressed deep frustration that they had nowhere to turn other than to sell their properties and to leave their farms, at a time of deeply depressed property values. The Brisbane Courier-Mail of 9 October also spoke of farmers' suicide rates as the rural crisis deepens, quoting from the comments of the Reverend Noel Park, the Director of Lifeline in Toowoomba, who said:

We are getting a disturbing number of telephone calls from people in absolute desperation. . . farmers who have been on the land for two or three generations who are unable to feed their families. The calls we are getting match the number of reports from country police on attempted suicides.

While the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is increasingly saying that his Government has the solutions, I think he is unreasonable to view the provisions of the rural adjustment scheme as the panacea, whether they be in respect of part B or, indeed, a new part D, covering extreme drought or hardship. I simply repeat my earlier question to the Minister: why has his Government done nothing in this respect?

To his credit, the Minister is listening and attempting to come to grips with the problem, in conjunction with his Queensland and New South Wales colleagues. However, much of the emphasis is rhetorical and seems to be on the periphery of the problem. Much of what has been achieved in recent weeks in conjunction with the States is simply window dressing, a point which a number of Queensland ALP Ministers have also made. I simply say to the Minister, in conclusion, that we need urgent action, not more confusing Cabinet rhetoric; time is running out fast for many out there on the land.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-On the east coast of Australia, and particularly central and northern New South Wales and a large part of Queensland, we are facing one of the worst droughts on record. It is probably as bad as or worse than the droughts of 1890, 1932, 1946 and 1982. But, as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) said, it has varied; when we look out of the window here we see beautiful green grass, and people in Victoria and Tasmania have been much more fortunate. It is one of the frustrating things about the driest continent on Earth, a continent of 3 million square miles, that in any decade there is always a severe drought in one part of our country, and there always will be, and there will always be an abundance of rain in another part.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is setting up a structure that individually targets those people most in need. That is why we have put our emphasis on the rural adjustment scheme, parts A, B and C. I can understand the frustration of farmers who have watched their crops die. I have seen my crops die. I have seen my friends' crops die. I can understand some farmers who are on the edge because their farm unit is small, because of the massive drop in commodity prices over the last two to three years, and because of a trade war in which we are victims and in which we have taken no part. They are now faced with a drought, which in many instances is a final straw. There is no doubt that over the next two to three years, maybe sooner, something like 20 to 30 per cent of Australian farmers in particular areas may lose their entire equity.

There are, sadly, some farmers whom nobody can help. There are others whom we can help, and we are doing it in two ways: not only through the rural adjustment scheme but also through rural counselling. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), I believe sincerely, mentioned his concern about suicides, something that touches us all. A very dear friend of mine took his own life only a few weeks ago.

The rural counselling service has done an outstanding job on the ground across this country in dealing on a local basis with families who are suffering trauma. It is hard for people who have been on the land for generations to face the reality that they do have to sell. There is no doubt about that. But we on this side of the House are not prepared to offer false hope or play on people's emotions to get cheap points or votes.

In regard to part A of the rural adjustment scheme, this year $74.9m has been allocated to improve farm structural adjustment and for the longer term. In part B, which is matched by the States, there is $13.6m for carry-on funds to maintain the farm and for fodder buying. In part C, which is the most traumatic, $57.5m has been allocated to help farmers who have lost their equity to leave the land with dignity. Part C has now been means tested and indexed, and that means that $34,000 is available for farmers to take with them to start life again. That money cannot be taken; it is `quarantined'. In other words, if a family owes $350,000, sells its property and only gains $200,000, it still takes that $34,000 with it to start a new life. It may not be compensation for a lifetime's work--it is certainly not. It cannot compensate for what people have lost, but it gives them the opportunity to start again. I think that is important.

In April 1991 the Commonwealth Government approved an increase in funding for the rural counselling service up to $2.6m for 1991-92. There are now 49 counselling services, employing 57 counsellors, throughout Australia. As I have said, they have done an outstanding job. The Minister and I are prepared to listen and take on board any constructive propositions put to us--either as a Government or in his capacity as Minister or mine as the chairman of the primary industries committee--which can help farmers in any way.

However, it is my view, and that of the Government, that subsidies are not the answer. In fact, instead of helping those most in need, subsidies tend to go to the wealthiest and to the distributors of products such as fodder, not to the farmers themselves. As I have said, part B of RAS can be used for fodder, water and agistment services. While in every drought it has been said that unless governments provide transaction based subsidies, particularly for fodder and agistment purposes, the viability of the national beef cattle herd and our meat export markets will be threatened, that has not necessarily occurred in the past. Fodder and water subsidies provided in previous years were not large enough to have a significant effect on this outcome. Part B of RAS is there to do just that.

I believe that freight and other subsidies are reactive rather than pre-emptive; they do not have the intended incentive effect and they are highly inequitable across industries. That is why we have included the whole structure in RAS to help primary producers. We did that because back in Queensland in 1988 drought relief was rorted. I well remember going to a public meeting in Monto with the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). I was accused of not doing enough for farmers because I would not agree to a subsidy of $40m to wipe out farm debt. While I was being accused by the State National Party and Federal National Party members in Queensland of not caring because I would not acquiesce to that, the former National Party State Government knew, and admitted after the public accounts inquiry, that its own structure of drought relief was being rorted. Some $15m was paid out in subsidies during one drought in Queensland. Of that, 84 per cent of users received only $5,000 or less; the remaining 16 per cent received 76 per cent of all subsidy payments. In other words, 16 per cent received $11.4m and 84 per cent received the difference--$4.6m.

That demonstrated once again that subsidies do not work for the people most in need. This is why the rural adjustment scheme is there, targeted specifically to help.
