This Bill proposes amendments to the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 to provide for the reporting and analysis of international telegraphic transfer data. The reporting of international telegraphic transfers will complement the existing requirements under the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 for cash dealers to report to the Cash Transaction Reports Agency (CTRA) those transactions which are either suspect or involve cash in excess of $10,000 and for individuals to report the export and import of currency in excess of $5,000. The existing reporting system fills a gap left by the removal of a system of tax screening arrangements and foreign currency controls which ceased to operate from 1 July 1990.

The success of the CTRA, as described in its recently tabled annual report, has been impressive. The degree of effectiveness of the agency, still in its infancy, reflects the enormous goodwill and cooperation of the financial sector in assisting law enforcement, and the growing expertise of our revenue and law enforcement agencies in dealing with the financial aspects of illegal activity.

This measure now proposed will assist in combating large scale tax evasion and organised crime. The trend in tax evasion and corporate crime is to internationalise illicit profits, and international telegraphic transfers are the principal means by which funds are channelled from Australia overseas. The reporting of the data to the CTRA will allow the easy collection, analysis and immediate dissemination to law enforcement agencies of accurate information relating to international telegraphic transfers of funds.

In March 1991 the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Financial and Public Administration--the Martin Committee--in considering the issue of international profit shifting found evidence of the perpetration of large scale revenue evasion, possibly of the order of $100m to $250m, and recommended that a system of monitoring and reporting international telegraphic transfers of funds be implemented, with the CTRA responsible for the establishment and administration of such a system.

The Martin Committee has indicated that the capture and analysis of telegraphic transfer data would add a significant dimension to the ability of the Australian Taxation Office and law enforcement agencies to strike at financial gain, which is the major incentive of international organised crime.

Existing reporting systems do not adequately provide for the monitoring of international transactions. This is a serious deficiency since it deprives the Australian Taxation Office of an important source of intelligence in its efforts to combat international profit shifting to avoid tax liability.

Some international telegraphic transfers have been reported to the CTRA in the form of suspect transactions. However, this is only the tip of the iceberg in international profit shifting activities. Telegraphic transfers are effected in a very impersonal manner without the counter contact which brings the staff member face to face with the customer in circumstances where he or she might notice something peculiar about the transaction. As pointed out in the Martin report, because of the sophistication of the abuse of withholding tax arrangements, the likelihood of the associated transactions being reported through the CTRA's reporting arrangements is minimal.

On the issue of tax avoidance, the Martin committee received evidence indicating that arrangements or schemes are operating in Australia which allow Australian residents to avoid their taxation obligations by paying 10 per cent withholding tax instead of personal or company rates of income tax. Some of the schemes are extremely complex and difficult to detect, involving circuitous routes through various countries, including tax havens, and can often reappear as legitimate transactions.

A feasibility study has shown not only the real need for law enforcement agencies to have access to information about such transfers to trace the profits of criminal activity for taxation and confiscation purposes, but also that many cash dealers are in a position to readily provide much of this information. The remainder is transmitted by telex. While the proposed legislation will require the reporting of transfers transmitted by telex, the Government is conscious of the burden that this could impose on those cash dealers who conduct a high volume of telex transfers and whose systems are not computerised. It is therefore proposed to exempt those cash dealers from reporting telex transfers until the telex systems are computerised. International telegraphic transfer data is already in electronic form for transmission through the SWIFT --Society for World-wide International Financial Telecommunication--system and can be duplicated by cash dealers and transmitted on line to the CTRA.

As I said earlier, the measures in the Bill will provide a necessary tool for detecting offshore tax rorts, which are believed to be flourishing, and for assisting in the appropriate assessment of tax liability. Conservative estimates are of revenue gains in excess of $37m per annum. The CTRA considers that 85 per cent of non-cash funds transfers are remitted offshore through the telegraphic transfer system. The Taxation Institute of Australia indicates how a substantial sum can slip through the reporting system as it currently operates. One instance is where, for example, $1m--perhaps the proceeds of a successful drug importation in the process of being laundered--is remitted to a tax haven by telegraphic transfer. This would not be reported since it is not in the form of cash.

In this respect, the current system is narrower in its scope than the previous tax screening system. Lost taxation revenue may, in fact, exceed $100m per year, according to the Martin report, with additional lost customs revenue estimated at $10m per year and proceeds of crime at $30m. In contrast, the cost of implementing the proposal is relatively modest. The outlay in the first two years will be $13.8m because of the capital investment in information technology facilities but will be less than $5m in subsequent years. There will also be costs to cash dealers, principally in the modification of computer equipment to duplicate existing data for transmission to the CTRA.

The Australian Bankers' Association and representatives of other major cash dealers groups have worked closely with officers of my Department and the CTRA in the development of this initiative, and I wish to thank them for their cooperation and support. This cooperation is continuing in the development of appropriate technology to permit the monitoring of such transfers to ensure the effectiveness of the scheme and its appropriateness to the practices of the finance industry. The Bill will make provision to protect banks, whether Australian or foreign, operating in Australia from any possible legal action which may arise in Australia from the banks complying with the reporting requirements.

The Bill also proposes two minor amendments to the CTR Act: first, to clarify the last point in time when a person is able to make a report to a Customs officer when bringing currency into or taking it out of Australia; and, secondly, to change the name of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency to the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre--AUSTRAC--and the name of the Act to the Financial Transaction Reports Act.

The Bill also includes a provision to clarify the obligation to report in section 15 of the Act. That section requires a person bringing into, or taking out of, Australia currency of a value greater than $A5,000 to make a report in a prescribed form to a Customs officer. An uncertainty was brought to light in a recent South Australian Supreme Court decision which held that a report could still be filed during a Customs baggage search without breach of the provision. The amendment clarifies this obligation by defining the last point in time when reports of such transfers can be made--namely, prior to baggage search or prior to being given permission to leave the Customs control area without search for inwards passengers, and the point where Customs officers inspect passports for outwards passengers. Provision is also made in relation to persons other than passengers--crew, for example.

The Bill will also amend the name of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency to the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre. This title will more accurately reflect the nature of the Agency's major operations since, particularly with the addition of the reporting of international telegraphic transfers, only a minor proportion of the Agency's operations will relate to cash transactions. For the same reason, the name of the Act will also be changed to the Financial Transaction Reports Act.

In conclusion, I stress that the country cannot afford to continue to suffer the vast revenue losses through tax and customs evasion or tolerate the removal offshore of the proceeds of some of our most serious crimes. The average Australian is tired of seeing the high fliers rort the system. The shareholders of this country are tired of seeing their investments moved offshore, seemingly without trace and certainly beyond their reach, often for the personal gain of unscrupulous manipulators. Lack of means to detect and trace such movements is a serious weakness in the system which must now be remedied.
I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Wilson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1991[COGNATE BILL:CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 October, on motion by Mr Baldwin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Before the debate is resumed on this Bill, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-We have been examining the adequacy of Government policies with regard to amendments to the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. There is no doubt about it: the Government's policies have been established as completely inappropriate, harsh and lacking in real understanding of the difficulties of manufacturing industries. The Government's lack of understanding and harshness is highlighted by two measures in particular that are contained within this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has identified, I believe, by its statements and by some of the attitudes expressed by Ministers, the difficulties and problems in the Australian community today. One would have to be blind not to recognise that there are huge and increasing queues of people seeking unemployment benefits. One would have to be both deaf and blind to fail to recognise that there is a massive 70 per cent increase in the number of bankruptcies in Australia today.

Despite the indications that the Government has belatedly noticed that there is high unemployment and a high level of bankruptcies, it has not been able to respond in an appropriate way. In the Government's industry statement, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) laid down a course of action for the Government. Little of it has been fulfilled, much has not been done, and the Government has not moved ahead to initiate reforms to the Australian way of life for which it is responsible so that the benefits can flow through to the community, and so that there can be an increase in productivity and efficiency in Australian industry, a creation of jobs in the process, and a better chance for all Australians. The Government, instead, has chosen to continue its destructive policies of high interest rates and, at the same time as running a high interest rate policy, it has chosen to reduce tariffs.

Nothing could be designed to dramatically destroy Australian manufacturing capacity more than running the dual policies of high interest rates and a reduction of tariffs. There is no compensatory feature for Australian job creators or Australian manufacturing industries. We have had the Government running the worst possible agenda for creating jobs and making Australia productive and efficient. It acknowledges the disaster that these policies are causing but is unable--it is hamstrung--to find remedies and alternatives.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be well aware that there has been a struggle within the Australian Labor Party over ideas as to who among the potential leaders of that Party can offer the best direction for the Australian people. Part of the reason for the struggle is the lack of direction the Government has given to Australians and the concern being expressed by the members of the Government and the whole community for the future of Australia in relation to job opportunities, the potential to buy a house and the potential to raise a family. Nothing has been done to increase efficiency or to reform our productivity levels, which are low when measured by world standards. Nothing has been done in the workplace to make Australians feel confident about their future.

The whole community knows about the difficulties that occurred at SPC and is aware that they are reflected right throughout workplace relations. In New South Wales a strike has been called for tomorrow or next week rather than trying to negotiate on the difficulties. Power hungry union leaders are clinging to their cars, their salaries and their expense accounts rather than trying to work through the problems.

There are two features of this legislation that are of particular interest to me. The first is the decision made by the Government to wipe out, ahead of time, tariff protection for a very small industry, an industry affecting two or three manufacturers. I refer to the manufacturers of audio tapes and audio players. The Opposition agrees to the predictable decline in the level of tariffs, and we endorse that process. But in this instance the Government has chosen to honour some foreign agreement and wind down the tariff more quickly than it indicated previously it would do.

The other feature that is of interest to me is that the Government has decided to give increasing preference to foreign manufacturers to enter Australia. The Government continually talks about a level playing field, that is, one where all self-interests are balanced. I do not think it really occurs in fact. But surely our self-interest in this area must be predictable as we gain efficiency for Australian manufacturing industries and not be so stupid as to give preferences to competitors where it is not warranted. We should be contracting the number of developing countries to which we provide a system of tariff preferences. There should be a systematic process of assessing those preferences and dealing with them.

Preference in this instance offers a 5 per cent margin for all dutiable items entering Australia where the general tariff rate is 5 per cent or higher, so there is a 5 per cent tariff. To give an example, if there is a 10 per cent tariff generally applying to a product being imported, developing countries which have a 5 per cent preference pay a rate of duty of 5 per cent and if the Australian rate of duty is 5 per cent or less, no tariff is paid. So a definite preference is given to developing countries. That may be all very well; it does give to some countries access to Australia at favoured rates. But when one comes to look at the schedule of the Customs Tariff Act, one finds that about 168 countries are designated as developing countries and have this favoured treatment.

The names of the countries are laid out in three parts. There are the islands of the South Pacific Forum, which are our near neighbours and friends and should not at any stage--certainly not in the near future--be considered for removal from the developing nation status. Then there are developing countries, including countries which are our competitors and selling their products on world markets. They are countries such as Brazil, Chile, Korea, Singapore and Taiwan, where I believe the standard of living is such that they could no longer be termed developing countries. It is time the Government looked at this issue. The Opposition has made a commitment to examine the developing country preferences given in relation to tariffs and re-order that process, because it is long past the time when that should be done.

The Government, however, instead of saying even that it will conduct an examination of this process, has recently added Hungary and Poland, and now Czechoslovakia and Namibia, to this legislation, so that the Government is increasing the list of countries that can export goods to Australia on a favoured basis. At the same time the Government is running down at an accelerated and unpredictable rate the protection for Australian industry. It is inconsistent and very damaging for the Australian community that the Government should adopt these attitudes.

Australian exports to developing countries are worth about $17 billion a year, accounting for about 36 per cent of Australia's exports. Imports from developing countries are worth about $12 billion, or about 23 per cent. However, 60 per cent of imports from what Australia terms developing countries are from Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore, China, Hong Kong and Malaysia, many of which could not be any longer regarded as developing countries.

It is time the Government took stock of where its inconsistent policies are leading Australia. There can be no confidence whilst it is so inconsistent. The Czechoslovak Republic will be added to the list in the legislation. Australia had about $63m worth of exports to Czechoslovakia in 1990. The balance of trade was $22m in Australia's favour. As to Namibia, we exported approximately $1.8m worth of goods, with a balance of trade of about $1.7m in our favour.

I understand the need for self-interest in these areas, but true self-interest is to be able to allow Australians to flourish and to work in their own place of habitation. The Government is not encouraging that. This legislation is minor legislation. The principles are prime principles, because the principles that the Government has applied in this legislation are ones that are destroying jobs and creating bankruptcies. What the Government needs to do is re-examine these principles of preference for developing countries. It needs to provide a predictable downturn in tariff protection so that Australian manufacturers and job creators know what is happening and can make appropriate investments. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-There are two Bills in this cognate debate: the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1991 and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. The purpose of the amendment in the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill is to increase the rate of excise on certain naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas, or LPG, and to reduce the rate of excise on aviation gasoline.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's demonstrated economic reserves of LPG are equivalent to about 30 years supply at current rates of production. However, in the absence of new projects, production of LPG is expected to decline from the current level to 1.6 million tonnes by the year 2000, particularly as the production from the Bass Strait fields declines. Refinery production of LPG as a by-product of petroleum refining is expected to remain fairly constant.

Demand for LPG in all its uses in Australia has grown by an annual average of 12 per cent in recent years--far faster, I add, than for other fuels. Demand for LPG is still growing rapidly at a rate which would require significant imports within a few years. Development of further LPG reserves will depend on the exploration for and development of oil and gas discoveries. That in turn will depend on developers receiving world market prices for their oil, gas and LPG. Only world prices will encourage companies to develop further new discoveries for the Australian market, and only world prices will induce explorers to spend the capital to provide future supplies.

We did enter into this debate last year when the Middle East crisis was on our hands and we saw an escalation in the cost of fuel. I wish we could isolate ourselves from oil price increases. But Australia can no more isolate itself from world oil and gas prices than it can isolate itself from world trade. If we cannot develop more LPG reserves, we will end up importing it--at world prices.

On 1 January this year we saw the introduction of deregulation of the LPG industry. The Prices Surveillance Authority no longer determines the producer-wholesale prices of LPG. The industry is now free to negotiate market prices for LPG. In place of its previous role, the PSA has increased monitoring of distributor and retail prices of LPG to ensure that there is no exploitation of consumers. If prices are found to have increased beyond a reasonable level, individual producers and marketers may find themselves declared under the provisions of the Prices Surveillance Act.

Liquefied petroleum gas in automotive use does have some environmental advantages over petrol, although its consumption still produces carbon dioxide and other exhaust emissions, and its environmental advantages should not be overstated. An important factor in dealing with environmental problems is getting the price signals right. In a more deregulated market, prices reflect more closely the real costs of supply and the nature of the fuel, including its environmental characteristics.

The full effects of deregulation are not likely to be evident for some time. There is no doubt that deregulation will be in the long term interests of consumers. Already there has been a great deal of interest in the market, with a number of large investments being planned and committed into infrastructure and distribution facilities. The seasonal shortages that have plagued the market in past years appear to have been overcome. Deregulation is giving greater confidence to producers. It is certainly becoming a more dynamic market, with healthy competition and more expansion being encouraged.

The increase in the rate of excise on LPG proposed in this Bill is for the period 1 April 1991 to 30 June 1991. The reason that the proposed increase will apply only from 1 April to 30 June is that from 1 July 1991 the excise on LPG will be replaced by a resource rent tax under the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Act 1991.

The reason for the increase in the rate of excise from $5.789 per kilolitre to $35.94 per kilolitre is that it reflects the higher export prices obtained for LPG during the Gulf war. The increase in the excise rate for naturally occurring LPG is estimated to result in an increase of $9.4m in excise receipts for the three months commencing 1 April 1991. The excise arrangements for LPG apply only to LPG from a limited range of sources, with LPG produced from refineries, onshore fields or fields that commenced production after 16 August 1977 excluded from the arrangements. The result is that only LPG produced in Bass Strait is covered by the arrangements.

The second amendment in this Bill refers to the excise on aviation gasoline which contributes towards recovering the costs of en route terminal navigation rescue and firefighting services and facilities where no specific charges apply for those services. In July 1991 the Civil Aviation Authority announced that it would remove rescue and firefighting services from capital city secondary airports. These included Bankstown, Essendon, Moorabbin, Archerfield, Parafield, and Jandakot in Western Australia. The CAA's decision to withdraw its rescue and firefighting services from the six secondary airports followed a comprehensive review of existing RFFS arrangements which involved input from the aviation industry, local authorities, metropolitan fire brigades and the Federal Airports Corporation.

The effect of this amendment will be to decrease the excise rate on avgas by 0.321c per litre from 27.395c per litre to 27.074c per litre. The reduction in the rate of excise and customs duty on the gasoline for use in aircraft will reduce the Commonwealth revenue by approximately $340,000 for 1991-92. The money appropriated to the CAA will accordingly be reduced by that amount.

The second Bill is the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. In 1966 Australia became the first country to introduce tariff preferences for developing countries. The previous speaker, the honourable member of Mitchell (Mr Cadman), seemed to be critical to some degree of our position on developing country preferences. The Australian system of tariff preferences for developing countries, ASTP, was established under a special waiver granted by the contracting parties to the GATT. It consisted of a non-reciprocal preferential agreement arrangement under which specified manufactured and semi-manufactured goods could be imported from developing countries free of duty or at reduced rates of duty subject to quota limitations on imports at the developing country preferential rate.

This system has been reviewed a number of times and the system currently in force addresses a wide range of concerns. Essentially, the current system provides a trade-off for the Australian domestic industry whereby a single low 5 per cent preference margin was introduced in return for wider coverage of imports from developing countries. In the March industry statement we announced the progressive exclusion of Singapore, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Korea--the four big tigers of Asia--from benefits under the Australian system of tariff preferences, and rightly so.

In 1989 Australian exports to developing countries amounted to $17 billion, accounting for 36 per cent of total Australian exports. Imports from developing countries amounted to $12 billion, accounting for 23 per cent of total Australian imports. That raises a very interesting point. We have a trade surplus of $5 billion--these are 1989 figures--with developing countries. When all politicians are under a bit of pressure, and particularly given that our rural sector is under pressure, it is easy to talk about the old McEwenism, the tariff monkey on our back, and to say, `Let us put up protection'. But the real losers would be Australian producers, in agriculture, manufacturing and in the service sector, because we have a trade surplus with these countries.

The other important thing is that, by allowing these countries to find markets, their standard of living will rise, consumer demand will rise and we will gain access to even bigger markets. It is often very hard to go out and tell that to people when things are tough. But it is the right way to go, and it was encouraging, when members of this House were in Brussels recently, that all political parties supported the right proposition, together, united. It is in our long term interests to break down the protectionism of the European Community and the USA. Australia is leading the way not only in free trade through the Cairns Group. It is not naive because, without that, we would not survive. Eighty per cent of our markets have to be found overseas. The fact is that we are leading the way in supporting these preferential rates for developing countries. In the long term it helps also the security in our region. When countries have access to markets, the likelihood of problems between countries is broken down, so it is a very beneficial process.

But we have to watch continually to see whether countries are improving their standard of living. A country comes to my mind as one that over time will also eventually pass into the category that Singapore, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Korea have. I refer to Thailand because its economy is improving dramatically. But at present Thailand is not one of those countries to be considered. These preferences are beneficial particularly when we have a trade surplus in our favour. Obviously, it will be hard to continue to argue such a large trade surplus with those countries because trade is about bilateral trade. We fill up ships with our products and send them to a country. It is commonsense and economically rational to send something back in those ships. Without back loading, the shipping companies would go broke and countries would not trade on that basis. So that is the very root of the problem, which is why these measures are beneficial.

Schedule 6 of this Bill, which is operative on and from 1 October 1991, accords developing country status to Czechoslovakia. The Government has also accorded that status to Namibia. It is sad and a tragedy that a country with such a great history as Czechoslovakia has to come under this proposition today--a country that suffered under the regimes of fascism and communism for so long and a country that has produced so many first class quality products. Let us hope that in a short time it will be able to move out of that category once again, but it is entitled to come under that category at present. Let us hope that, with a lot of wisdom and hard work, those Eastern bloc countries will get back to where they once were. The countries involved in the Renaissance were returned to the Dark Ages for far too long.

This Bill will also give effect to certain of Australia's obligations under the Florence agreement. In accordance with this agreement, Australia will remove duties on such goods as magnetic recording media, film, catalogues, bibliographical information, transparencies and aids to the disabled. To date, 79 nations, including the United States, Japan and the European Community nations, have acceded to the Florence agreement.

In January this year the Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1991 was assented to. Among other things, this Act amended the Customs Tariff Act 1987 to allow duty free importation from 1 January 1991 of invalid carriages, for example, wheelchairs. However, the amendments did not extend to parts of invalid carriages which currently are dutiable at a rate of 17 per cent. The amendment proposed by this Bill is intended to correct this anomaly. The cost of removing the duty for parts of wheelchairs, in terms of Customs duty forgone, is estimated at about $100,000 per annum.

The Burnett region of my electorate around Gayndah and Mundubbera is a vast citrus growing area, one of the biggest and best in Australia. The Queensland citrus industry has experienced delays and rejection of some consignments in the past due to the variable presence of symptoms of the disease black spot on fruit. A recent protocol agreement will mean that Queensland suppliers can now export with greater certainty as New Zealand will have more assurance that products shipped under agreement will meet their quarantine requirements.

Last year saw the introduction of stricter controls for the labelling of imported fruit juice. I have recently met with the Committee of Direction of Fruit Marketing in Brisbane to discuss a submission for stricter controls on the labelling of fresh fruit and vegetables, and processed products as well. We require the agreement of all States. A committee of inquiry is under way at the moment. I have stressed the need for this to be the first cab off the rank in investigation. As soon as we have this labelling, consumers will be able to use their own preference to choose Aussie products. Without resorting to the tariff barriers of the past, I am convinced that we will be able to reduce the demand for products that are imported from overseas in our supermarkets and not be contrary to the GATT. Already the Queensland banana growers are promoting the Broncos, the best rugby league team in the competition. If we can get more promotion like that, we will be able to outdo the imported products because we produce first class quality products.

TALK.START.PARA: —-They should call that team the Mangoes.

—-As the Minister at the table says, we certainly would not agree to that in Queensland. We are very proud--as I am sure the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) is--of the Broncos. We are hard done by every year.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian citrus growers have recently sought Commonwealth assistance to counter sharp falls in world orange juice prices, which have eroded producer returns. After examination of the problems facing the citrus industry, the Government decided to provide a grant of $2m to the Australian Horticultural Corporation, the AHC, over the period 1990 to 1993 for special marketing projects for Australian fresh fruit juice and fresh oranges. The AHC estimated that $1.1m would be spent in 1990-91 and revised estimates were submitted. The implementation of this program was delayed with the result that no request for funds for 1990-91 was received. The AHC estimates that it will use approximately $833,000 of the funds in the 1991-92 financial year. Provision of the funds is expected to result in increased promotion and marketing of fresh Australian oranges and Australian fruit juice.
In the August 1991 edition of the Australian Citrus News, the Chairman of the Australian Citrus Growers Federation said:

Overseas markets were tough and competitive, demanding quality fruit delivered reliably and on time. The citrus industry's target of doubling exports within five years would be reached only with a professional and coordinated approach to growing, packing and marketing.
He stated that there was increased overseas interest in Australian oranges this year after heavy crop losses in last December's Californian freeze.

The amendment in schedule 4 of this Bill defines orange juice to include products of oranges, regardless of methods of derivation. This amendment restores the intended rates of assistance for orange juice following representations from the citrus industry. Currently, orange pulp wash concentrate is classified as a food preparation and as such imports are dutiable at a general rate of 10 per cent. The effect of the proposed amendment will be to increase the general rate applicable to 18 per cent. I am very pleased to support both these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Atkinson Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I welcome the opportunity to make some remarks in today's debate on the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. The Bill before the House is largely a housekeeping exercise but includes some important provisions which deserve comment. This debate is occurring at a time when the Government's industry policy is in a state of chaos. Despite the promise of a new start in the March ministerial statement, Building a Competitive Australia, this Bill highlights the Government's piecemeal approach to industry and trade reform.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill before the House contains a number of schedules and I will offer some brief comments on those which have major significance. Schedule 1 is a housekeeping provision and amends the principal Act by providing free rates of duty for pre-tanned bovine leather. This provision corrects an anomaly created by conversion to the harmonised tariff and is effective from 1 July 1988.

Schedule 2 is a more complex matter. Honourable members will be aware that this amendment is in response to the 1990 report of the Industry Commission dealing with tariff penalties, as they apply to aids and appliances for the disabled. At the time of the Commission's report, the general rate of tariff for wheelchairs was 17 per cent, with 12 per cent for developing countries. The Commission recommended that the tariff on wheelchairs be set at 15 per cent on 1 July 1991 and then be reduced by 5 per cent each year until it reaches zero on 1 January 1994. The Commission concluded that a reduction in such tariffs was unlikely to have a severe adverse effect on local manufacturers. The Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1991 went further than the Commission's recommendations and from 1 January 1991 the import of wheelchairs has been free of duty.

Schedule 2 corrects an anomaly--forewarned by the coalition--and it reduces the tariffs on wheelchair parts, currently dutiable at 17 per cent, to zero. This amendment has the support of the coalition. I would suggest that the Government was untidy in its amendments in the Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1991 and the anomaly should not have arisen. The need for this amendment highlights the danger and stupidity of ad hoc tariff changes. The Government should have a policy which is comprehensive and which Australian industry understands and can anticipate.

Schedule 4 redefines orange juice to include the products of oranges, regardless of derivation. As part of its economic statement in May 1988, the Government announced that the tariff on citrus juices would be converted to an ad valorem rate and be phased to 15 per cent by 1 July 1992 and 10 per cent for developing countries.

In recent years, the import of Brazilian citrus produce has had a significant impact on the production and prices of Australian orange juice. The relatively low prices and the increase in availability of Brazilian produce and the sharp falls in world orange juice prices have resulted in Australian citrus growers seeking Commonwealth assistance. This amendment is part of the Federal Government's response. Federal Cabinet has rejected a proposal for a price underwriting scheme for oranges, as proposed by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), and a price stabilisation scheme, as proposed by the citrus industry.

It appears that the effect of this amendment is to give additional protection from imports to the local producers of orange pulp wash. Under current provisions, pulp wash concentrate is classified as a food preparation and imports attract a duty of 10 per cent, and 5 per cent for developing countries. The effect of this amendment will be to increase the tariff to 18 per cent, and 13 per cent for developing countries, as from 10 April 1991.

Schedule 5 reduces the duty rate for aviation gas by 0.321c per litre following a decision by the Civil Aviation Authority to withdraw its rescue and firefighting services from capital city secondary airports. Such an airport is the Moorabbin airport which is situated in my electorate of Isaacs. Whilst I do not wish to debate at length the merits of the decision of the Civil Aviation Authority, I wish to place on record my concern that the withdrawal of the rescue and firefighting services from airports such as Moorabbin may lead to a significant decline in the safety of users at such airports. I note the concerns of the United Firefighters Union of Australia in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 2 July 1991, which states:

The specialised airport units, reached the scene of an accident at any of these airports, within two minutes, while it would take up to eight minutes for outside fire brigades to arrive. Added to this, they have not been properly trained in dealing with an aviation accident, which is a specialised field.

Similar concerns have also been expressed to me by representatives from the firefighting service at Moorabbin airport. Schedule 5 also implements measures to enable Australia's partial accession to the 1950 UNESCO Florence agreement on the importation of goods of an educational, scientific and cultural character. Included with these changes is the introduction of zero duty for audio cassettes as from 1 July 1991, which previously attracted a duty of 17 per cent.

Schedule 6 includes Czechoslovakia and Namibia as countries eligible for developing country status and preferential duty rates. This provision gives these two countries a discount of 5 per cent off the general industry assistance tariffs over 5 per cent. In the March 1991 economic statement, Building a Competitive Australia, the Government announced that tariff preferences for Singapore, Taiwan, Hong Kong and South Korea will be phased out by 1 July 1992. While I welcome the removal of these countries off the list of developing countries for trade preference, I am concerned that this Bill seeks to add additional countries on an ad hoc basis. Rather than engaging in an overall review of countries receiving tariff preference, we see here yet another example of policy on the run. I can see why Namibia is deserving of preferential treatment, but how can it be argued that Czechoslovakia and Namibia are deserving of the same treatment? Czechoslovakia is an industrialised country. Certainly its development has been hampered by its Eastern bloc involvement, but to describe it as developing is certainly generous.

Honourable members will be well aware of Czechoslovakian products such as Zetor tractors, Skoda cars, fine glassware and crystal, to name just a few. Yet this Bill seeks to place Czechoslovakia on the same level as Namibia. I find this difficult to understand. If we continue the process of extending developing country status to more and more countries, then this continues to undermine Australian industry and it negates the whole process of phased and predictable tariff reductions. It is even harder to accept when I see that the inclusion of Czechoslovakia will cost $1.7m per annum in lost duty, while the inclusion of Namibia will cost the princely sum of $7,000.

The coalition does not oppose the changes to Australian protectionism. We believe that in many cases the level of protectionism is a burden on the community and industry itself. Protectionism encourages resource misallocation, the development of inward looking industries and a lack of efficiency. As a result, the coalition is supportive of any moves to reduce this burden and to make Australia more competitive.

However, the very important difference between the coalition's policy and the Government's policies is that the coalition will ensure that these reductions in tariffs are in conjunction with major micro-economic reforms. This would include reforming the industrial relations system, including the dismantling of the centralised wage fixing system, eliminating inefficiencies in transport, cleaning up the waterfront and opening up the telecommunications sector, to name just a few. Unlike the Government, we would therefore be addressing the issues of low productivity, high interest rates and an artificially high currency. As a result, business will be able to compete in a fair and competitive environment. The barriers and hurdles which currently exist and cost industry in this country approximately $17.5 billion per annum in the micro-economic reform area alone will be removed and the need for protection will diminish. But it is imperative that the necessary micro-economic reforms are in place before we remove the protection or else we will send Australian industry to the wall.
The search and desire for a level playing field is admirable, but let us not create a playing field that has lush green grass at one end and a mud patch at the other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise this afternoon to join the cognate debate on the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2). This Bill is quite a broad ranging Bill. It covers topics such as import duty payable on wheelchairs, import duty on orange juice and excise payable on aviation gasoline. The theme of the Bills is import duties and excise rates.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that import duties certainly add to the cost of goods that we supposedly do not produce in Australia. The added costs are a burden on all Australians. Some of the industries that tariffs seek to protect include the motor car industry and the textile clothing and footwear industry. In the area of excise rates we are really talking about duties which fund services provided by the Commonwealth; in other words, they were originally designed to fund services provided on a user-pay basis.

Both topics play a crucial role in Australia's economic well-being. I would like to highlight a number of inconsistencies propagated by this Government in relation to the avgas excise. This Excise Tariff Amendment Bill will reduce the rate of excise on gasoline for use in aircraft by a mere 0.321c per litre. It is an infinitesimal amount. The decrease will have effect from 1 July 1991. The rationale behind the proposed reduction in the avgas excise, as explained in the second reading speech, is the withdrawal of the Civil Aviation Authority's rescue and firefighting service from the capital cities' secondary airports.

Originally, avgas was legitimised as a fee for service rather than a revenue raising tax. I agree with the principle. It is a very sound principle. The theory then is that if a service is withdrawn, it is costing the customer less, and therefore the product becomes cheaper. However, to be truly equitable and consistent in this debate, fuel excise paid on avgas by primary producers in agricultural production should be subject to an excise rebate similar to the diesel fuel rebate. We have a situation with excise where a diesel fuel rebate exists to cover agricultural production and mining.

Remote Australian properties are not privy to an advanced aviation infrastructure. There is certainly no debate in my electorate or in towns such as Birdsville or Charleville about a third runway, which is certainly advanced aviation infrastructure. In the inland of Australia, many aeroplane and helicopter pilots never see infrastructure such as that or airports as advanced as the Canberra airport. In fact, the taxes that they pay on this aviation gas is contributing to the overall aviation infrastructure in Australia today. In 1990, 23 per cent of the total flying hours in Australia were spent on agricultural aerial work. That sort of work entails mustering with helicopters or light aeroplanes, checking water installation facilities, checking where flood waters are and how stock are faring during flood time and, in some cases, dropping fodder to stock stranded by flood waters, and many other day to day operations on a rural property.

In 1990-91 approximately $6.5m in avgas excise was paid by the agricultural sector alone. A typical property in the inland of Australia uses approximately 3,000 litres of avgas a year. That equates to about $700 or $800 per year for each property in inland Australia which has an aeroplane or a helicopter; people are paying for a service from which they receive no benefit. Of course, larger enterprises will be paying much more than that. This is an inequity; it is an anomaly which should be addressed. It equates to a tax on production, because no service is provided by the payment of this excise. It is a cross-subsidy which is paid by the agricultural sector to the overall aviation infrastructure of Australia, and the agricultural sector receives no benefit from it.

I hope the Minister looks at this inequity. It is an area where I believe this Government could simply introduce a Bill to allow avgas to be exempt from excise. In the same way as there is a diesel fuel rebate, there is no reason why avgas could not be exempt from the payment of excise in the agricultural sector.

Import duties are also racked with anomalies and discrepancies. The amendment proposed by the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill serves to correct one such anomaly in the Customs Tariff Act 1987. This Act allowed for the duty free importation of wheelchairs without providing the same concession for wheelchair parts. This Bill rectifies that, but it took four years to rectify a very simple anomaly.

I wonder how long it will take the Minister to address another anomaly that I see. I draw the attention of the House to the levelling of an import duty of 15 per cent on a biological insecticide not produced in Australia but imported from overseas--bacillus thuringiensis, or BT for short. BT occurs naturally in the environment, mainly in the soil, and, when ingested, reduces both feeding and the reproductive efficiency of the adult insect. It is a very important breakthrough. The bacterium is particularly proficient in the control of the cotton bollworm and it is being hailed by authorities as the most environmentally friendly cotton insecticide for the 1990s and for the year 2000 and beyond.

The insecticide is imported from the United States and attracts a 15 per cent import duty, resulting in an Australian retail price of $17.50 a litre. The Australian producer pays at least 50 per cent more for this product than his counterpart in the United States pays. At this price, with that impost of a 15 per cent excise tax, there is little incentive for growers to use the insecticide and little incentive for producers, who are very conscious of the costs of their inputs, to move to a biologically friendly insecticide.

The Government has ignored repeated calls to remove the 15 per cent tax and in so doing is prejudicing the future of the insecticide BT for pest control in the Australian cotton industry. Furthermore, the Government's inaction is at the expense of the environment, the local cotton growing industry and Australia generally. At the moment the Australian cotton industry is undergoing significant expansion. There are many farmers in the wheat belts of Australia who are moving into dry land cotton as a result of the corrupt world prices that are currently applying to the world wheat market, and that, of course, is a direct result of the activities of the Europeans and the Americans and the subsidies that they pay on the export of their wheat.

The cotton industry is an important industry. We should be trying to encourage its further expansion. Cotton production in this current financial year, 1991-92, is expected to rise by a mammoth 37 per cent over last year's figures. Much of this increase is expected in the dry land areas. The industry is not asking for a subsidy; the industry is requesting the removal of an import duty that is discouraging a technological advance that is going to benefit the environment. I would have thought that, if a government were environmentally conscious and aware of the need to get safer and better herbicides into our agricultural sector, the removal of this 15 per cent import duty would be commonsense.

The wool industry represents a further example of the iniquitous and illogical import duty regime of this Federal Government. In 1988 this Government increased the tariff on the finer end of the wool and fabric market, the cool wool area. Prior to this date there was a 2 per cent tariff on fine wool materials. It is very important to look at the timing, because 1988 was the time of very high wool prices in Australia and I think this Government thought, `Let's go for some money; let's see if we can rip a bit out of the wool industry'. It raised the tariffs from 2 per cent to 40 per cent, and it took 1 1/2 years of lobbying by industry to get lightweight wool fabrics exempted from such a tariff. The Government removed the tariff on that imported lightweight wool, which really only fits into the definition of wool of 125 grams per square metre, in other words, fabrics which are of shirt material weight. The Government left in place tariffs on wools in the cool wool category, that is, dresses, suits and apparel wear generally. The cool wool fabrics fit into the area of 125 to about 250 grams per square metre. These fabrics are not manufactured in Australia and still attract a 35 per cent tariff.

I can only imagine that this was due to the lobbying of some of our wool processors in Australia who do not make these products now but who said, `Maybe one day we will' or `We would if there were a greater demand for them in Australia'. It is illogical to have a 35 per cent import duty on a product that we do not make in Australia. We should be encouraging manufacturers of clothes in Australia to import some of these fabrics. There is a huge market out there for products at this end of the market and it would be commonsense to remove that tariff and allow the ready to wear products to be manufactured in Australia. Whilst we do not make the material, we could certainly make the suits and dresses, and add some value to our wool industry by way of removing these tariffs, which are a crazy 35 per cent at the moment.

In my electorate I have an expanding citrus industry. It is in the central Queensland area of Emerald. A very innovative farmer moved into the area a number of years ago and he draws his water from the Fairbairn Dam. It is pertinent that I should touch on what is going to happen to the citrus industry as a result of this Bill. The citrus industry, like every rural industry today, is battling the destructive Labor Party policies which have failed to address the real problems of food imports and labelling of fresh food products as distinct from manufactured or processed food products. The Government has still not addressed adequately, as far as I am concerned, the issue of anti-dumping and countervailing duties. To highlight that allegation, last year alone Australia imported a mammoth $2.2 billion worth of foreign food which Australian producers could well have supplied.

Further, on the citrus industry side of things, fresh orange imports in 1990-91 totalled almost 10,000 tonnes, a 40 per cent increase over the year before; that is, a 40 per cent increase in the importation of fresh oranges into Australia over the 1989-90 figure. Is it any wonder that the citrus industry is calling for some action on labelling, anti-dumping and countervailing duties?

The real tragedy in this figure is that there exists no requirement in Australia to label unpackaged fresh food products. Australian horticulturalists and citrus growers who pay for the promotion of Australian fresh fruit and vegetables are unwittingly promoting the market for foreign growers. It is very difficult today to determine at a shop anywhere the difference between an Australian grown orange, a Brazilian orange or one from California. If we had requirements that they be labelled as such, I believe the fresh food industry, our Australian producers of oranges, would be a lot happier. They pay levies for the promotion of their product.

The Australian consumer is the other person involved in this debate. The Australian consumer is not permitted to make a really informed choice as to the country of origin of these fresh foods. If it were to be a requirement that these products be labelled, I believe the Australian consumer would be choosing fresh Australian products rather than some of the imports. With the well-being of the primary industry sector in Australia at stake right now, this Government must ensure as a matter of urgency that an effective labelling regime covers fresh food as well as processed foods.

In the area of citrus, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill corrects yet another anomaly which defines orange pulp wash concentrate as a food preparation attracting a general rate of 10 per cent, as opposed to a juice, which has a general rate of 18 per cent. The definition has been amended and, as proposed in the Bill, pulp wash will attract the 18 per cent duty.

As I have outlined, this Government must go a lot further in remedying other anomalies that exist under the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. It must do this as a matter of urgency. We must be prepared to ensure that there is fair play and a level playing field. The way to do that and to ensure against subsidised imports is to ensure that we have adequate anti-dumping laws and countervailing duties that will apply in cases where there are clear breaches of the law. In many instances it takes up to one and two years to get a case heard. We must at the same time encourage our Australian agriculture, which is the most efficient in the world, by promoting responsible economic policies.
Whilst I support the changes in this Bill, I believe they have not gone far enough. I hope the Minister acts to remove the other excises and import duties to which I have referred today.
