TALKER.NAME: Mr LLOYD
TALKER.ROLE: -Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Rice Levy Bill establishes the industry and government research partnership on a more formal basis. It brings it into line with the partnerships existing, I believe very successfully, with a large number of other rural industries where there is a dollar for dollar industry-government payment arrangement for research up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production for that particular industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The rice industry has given a good lead to other industries, even though it has been rather late in coming into this formal arrangement. Last year it collected $166,000 in voluntary levies. Usually one of the problems with voluntary levies is that no money is collected; that is why we have statutory levies. But it is interesting that the rice industry has been able to obtain that amount of money. The total expenditure by the rice growers last year was $585,000, of which the maximum part beyond the $166,000 was made up by a contribution from the rice growers' cooperative pool.

The particular structure of the rice industry is that it is concentrated in the Riverina area of New South Wales and, to a lesser extent, in the Burdekin area of Queensland. I am talking here more of New South Wales than Queensland. I do not mean to be nasty to Burdekin; it is just that I happen to know the New South Wales situation better.

The structure of the industry has given it an ability to do certain things which I think other industries cannot do as well or as easily. One is to make that payment out of the general pool for the rice industry. Secondly, this industry is able to have a far better communication and accountability arrangement than those of many other industries.

There is criticism from time to time along the following lines, `Is this really what the industry wants? Did the industry really agree to that amount of money for a research levy?'. On the basis of the information that I have obtained, one can say that for the rice industry the answer must definitely be yes, because a high percentage of the total number of growers attend their annual meetings, this matter is discussed and a motion is passed. The industry also has a good feedback by way of a newsletter. It is a good model for many other industries.

Another reason why it is a good model relates to value adding. The new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) keeps talking about value adding. Everybody has been talking about value adding, or doing value adding, for a long time when it has been sensible to do so. Some have done it better than others. Once again, I think the rice industry has been good in this regard in that it has been gaining better value from the market by producing packeted goods and so forth.

The rice industry is an important industry in the Riverina area of New South Wales and the Burdekin. Close to one million tonnes of rice is being produced. It is a world leader in efficiency of production, and 85 per cent of the product is exported. If fair access to international markets were to be given to Australian rice, production could expand quite considerably, because the Australian industry can compete. But rice is subject to considerable restrictions in international trade. Japan is well known for its restriction, but it is not quite as well known that Taiwan and Korea also have complete restrictions on importing rice. There are also restrictions in a number of South East Asian countries. Many people would think that surely these countries could produce rice more cheaply than Australia. They cannot. The price in Japan, and I believe also in Taiwan, is three to four times the cost of production in Australia.

This raises the importance of the Uruguay Round of GATT. The bipartisan parliamentary delegation has been to Europe, and prior to that it was in the United States. Our focus tends to be on Europe and, to a lesser extent, the United States. But if there is a successful GATT round, many of these restrictions against agricultural exports to a whole range of South East Asian countries would, over a period, be reduced and fairer trade would operate for our products. This is where our real market opportunities are, and is very significant in terms of the advantages to Australia of a successful Uruguay Round.

Also, of course, the rice industry is subject to import competition in Australia, and there are no restrictions on that. It is interesting that some of those imports are from countries which subsidise their exports and from countries that do not allow our rice to be exported back to them. Hopefully, a GATT round will sort that out.

The new levy arrangement--that is, the more formal dollar for dollar arrangement--will raise about $600,000, to a total of $1m to $1.2m. Previously the Government had contributed only $203,000, that is, $166,000 on a dollar for dollar basis plus an additional $37,000 grant. So over a couple of years there will be a significant increase in the amount of money available for research. I should make the point that the New South Wales Government is also a major provider of research assistance, to the value of about $2m, through research farm arrangements.

The rice industry has another positive feature with regard to its rice levy arrangements for research, and that is that it wants to maintain a stable budget for its research activities. Rice is subject to fairly corrupt international pricing arrangements and differences in production from year to year. My understanding is that to provide stability in that research budget, the industry, when it knows what the level of production and the price will be, will actually determine a figure by regulation each year. That will allow the budget to be stable. That is another good point with regard to this particular arrangement that the rice industry wants.
The coalition will support the legislation, and I commend the rice industry again for some very positive features in that very important regional industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-At the outset, I would like to take this opportunity to commend all research and development corporations on the excellent work they are doing. Research carried out in Australia has made a vital contribution to the superb track record of farmers in improving the efficiency of production. Commodity specific R& spending is a major component of the total R& effort. The rural industry research funds are financed by producer levies matched, in terms of expenditure, by government subsidies.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government believes that there should be close industry involvement in the determination of research priorities. Among other benefits, this involvement will facilitate the development of effective strategies for research and it will lead to a higher rate of adoption of research results.

A review of the corporation model for funding research and development is currently being undertaken within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. The review will assess the influence of the corporation model on the effectiveness and accountability of research and development funding in the primary industries and energy portfolio. The review is to be conducted by Dr Alexander Lascelles and Mr Tony Gleeson. They will be working for about four months, as I understand it, on the review and will submit their report in December this year.

This Rice Levy Bill provides for the imposition of a levy on rice produced in Australia to raise funds for a research and development program for the rice industry. Funds raised by the proposed levy will be matched by the Commonwealth up to a maximum of 0.5 per cent of the rice industry's gross value of production. As the previous speaker, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) said, this is in line with the practice in so many other primary industries where we have seen this R& funding come in--and it is so good to see.

Australia produced 748 kilotonnes of rice in 1988-89, compared with 741 kilotonnes in 1987-88. The gross value of Australian rice production in 1988-89 was $133m, compared with $117m in 1987-88. The largest purchasers of Australian rice are Papua New Guinea, Hong Kong, the Pacific islands, the Middle East and New Zealand. As the honourable member for Murray quite rightly pointed out, while we do look to Europe and the United States for trade access for our products, it is in the Pacific Rim area and Asia that our real future and opportunities lie. With this industry in particular it is in these countries that we have a great opportunity.

Production of rice in Australia is centred in two geographical zones--in the Riverina district of south-western New South Wales and, closer to home for me, in north Queensland in Home Hill and Ayr, in the Burdekin. Last year production totals made records for both areas. In New South Wales, a total harvest of some 900,000 tonnes of paddy was achieved from sowings which had not increased. This has resulted from a combination of improved farming practices and the breeding of better varieties. That is the key to profitability for farmers. If we can get that productive capacity up on the same acreage, our costs overall come down.

In Queensland, production of some 23,000 tonnes of paddy followed settlement by the Queensland Government of new farms, consequent upon completion of another stage in the Burdekin irrigation project. In both areas paddy rice is milled, packed, financed and sold by totally grower owned cooperatives. The vast majority of rice growers are members of their respective cooperatives.

The principal issues facing both cooperatives are the establishment and maintenance of export markets in an increasingly contested international environment, and the maintenance of market shares in a competitive and open Australian market. There is no doubt that the cooperatives in the rice industry are very good. In regard to a free market economy--and I have always been a leader in the charge in that regard--we must not forget the very successful cooperatives in agriculture. It comes back to administration. If we look at my own area we see that the Isis cooperative mill has been successful through all the years of drought. It now has irrigation because it has a good board of directors. Of course, other areas--Babinda comes to mind--had problems in years gone by because of poor directors. But the rice industry has good directors, with sound business management skills, and that is why it has been so successful.

With such a high degree of export orientation, the principal concern of the industry is obviously related to levels of international rice prices and market access. No other rice exporting country sells such a high proportion of its output on overseas markets. Of course, that applies to the majority of our rural commodities. The high level of government intervention in the international rice trade gave it a high level of prominence in the GATT round. The Australian rice industry has very much to gain from a positive outcome of the GATT agricultural trade negotiations.

Access to the Japanese market and allegations by a Japanese consumer group that Australian rice is contaminated with chemical residues have recently been the subject of media attention. Access of Australian rice producers to the Japanese domestic market could provide a significant boost for the Australian industry. I add that our rice is better than Japanese rice. We need to see the Japanese, who lead the world in so many areas, finally coming to grips with this protection and pulling down the barriers. They do not need protection to be competitive--they have proven that in many areas and they have to do it in agriculture. The Japanese market consumes approximately nine million tonnes of rice per annum--a massive amount. Currently, entry into the Japanese market of Australian rice is prohibited.

The Rice Levy Bill 1991 gives effect to the establishment of funding for a rice research scheme. The Australian rice industry requested early in 1991 that a rice research fund be established by statutory levy and that the fund be under Rural Industry Research and Development Corporation management. The new funding arrangements will allow the industry to establish a broader based cooperative research program and to widen the scope of grower funded research. The arrangements will also allow the industry to continue a major commitment to research in order to maintain its competitive export and domestic marketing position.

In conclusion, I would like to make the following observation: when we look at large grower organisations we always tend to think that it is the bigger ones--whether it be the UGA or the Cattlemen's Union of Australia--which have all the clout and produce all the leaders. That is not the case at present. It is interesting to note that the President of the National Farmers Federation is a rice producer. I was very pleased to be in his company, standing shoulder to shoulder with him, while taking on the Europeans in Brussels recently. The President of the Queensland Farmers Federation, Lindsay Hall, is also a rice producer from the Burdekin. So both Graham Blight, President of the NFF, and Lindsay Hall, President of the QFF, are rice producers.

It is interesting to note that finally small producer groups are being taken notice of within their own organisations and structure. I think that is very important. Both these farm leaders have shown great ability at a time when rural Australia is facing one of its biggest challenges. Certainly now, with the double whammy of record drought in a large part of eastern Australia and a crush in commodity prices over the last two years--one of the greatest challenges agriculture has faced since the 1890 depression--these two men are doing an admirable job. I would be very pleased to work with them in a constructive way.

It is interesting to note that this industry, which has often been regarded as so small, has now thrown up the two leaders, in my home State and nationally, of producer organisations. I wish them well in the challenging fight ahead that we must face together if we are to overcome the vagaries of corrupted world markets, and work through with the distribution of RAS funds to try to save as many farmers as possible who are facing a crisis at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: --I rise to support the Rice Levy Bill 1991. This legislation gives effect to the establishment of a levy for the funding of a rice research scheme from July 1992. Rice growers have long realised the benefit to their industry of investing in research and development. Some $700,000 of growers' funds are provided annually towards rice production research.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the task of the industry's Rice Research Committee to prioritise growers' research needs and provide this funding to research and advisory agencies to address the priorities. The industry's annual research and development budget is around 2 to 3 per cent of farm gate value of production, a considerable amount of which is expended on produce development and has led to an impressive range of value added rice products in the marketplace.

In both the New South Wales and Queensland industries, finance for rice research has been a specific budget allocation which has been recouped through a voluntary levy on rice growers. Last year growers contributed $166,500. The Commonwealth matched this and in addition provided a $37,294 grant through the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation to take its total contribution to $203,848.

The Ricegrowers Association of Australia has requested this legislation so that it can broaden its major commitment to research in order to maintain its competitive export and domestic marketing position. The industry produces around 800,000 tonnes of paddy rice per year, with a gross value of production in 1989-90 of $148m. About 85 to 90 per cent of the production is exported to around 30 countries and is one of our rural industries which practices value adding, with the industry packaging and marketing its own brand of products.

The industry's support for this legislation is demonstrated by the fact that the following motion was passed unanimously at the Association's recent annual conference, which the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) and I attended:

That Annual Conference endorse the Rice Research Committee's proposal to enter into a matching funding arrangement for rice research within the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation, commencing July 1992.

The rate of the levy for each rice variety and the season to which the levy applies will be specified by the Minister after accepting recommendations made to him by the State rice marketing boards on levy rates. However, this legislation sets a maximum levy of $2 a tonne, which can be amended only by the Parliament. The levy is payable by the producer and will apply to rice produced in Australia and delivered to a processor of rice.

The justification for this levy and the success and progressiveness of the Rice Research Committee of the Ricegrowers Cooperative Ltd is exemplified by the variety of research projects it undertook in 1990-91. One of its major research projects was aimed at developing shorter season, higher yielding rice varieties of medium and long grain types with improved and appropriate quality. Improved cold tolerance and seedling vigour are also priorities, as well as maintaining pure seed of all varieties. It is important that this research produces a high yielding, top quality, shorter season medium grain, as it would be able to use the better part of the season to grow and it would require less water. This would then lower the cost of rice growers' largest input and allow water saved to be used to produce other income. We all know the importance of this water in Australia, the driest of the continents.

The release of a new fragrant rice variety, Goolarah, the direct result of research by the Rice Research Committee, is a milestone for the industry and it fills a gap in its produce range. Its success will hopefully see fragrant rice imports disappear. Evaluation of rice grain quality was also a major research project. This program aims to evaluate the quality of cross-breds from the rice breeding program. The factors that influence rice grain quality are described and measured; namely, grain appearance, milling yield, cooking behaviour, market and consumer preference and processing requirements. Special emphasis is being given to evaluating Japanese texture and flavour characteristics, Bahai-type quality and fragrant rice.

The Rice Research Committee is dedicating an increasing portion of its budget to sustainable resource use in rice growing. Two specific research projects currently under way are aimed at reducing groundwater accessions under rice by soil modification and optimising rice production within sustainable environmental constraints. These will receive $330,000 funding from the rice industry. As well, sustainability of resource use is a feature of all other projects the industry funds.

The research projects I have just mentioned are only a few of the many being carried out by the Rice Research Committee. Some other projects include rice weeds research, predicting rice crop fertiliser requirements, improving rice seedling establishment and optimising rice production within sustainable environmental constraints. These projects and others will benefit from the research levy being discussed today.

Not only is the Rice Research Committee experiencing success with its research, but its long term objectives are now reaching fruition. Firstly, the Committee has been able to increase the Federal Government's contribution to the rice research program from around $50,000 four years ago to $336,000 in 1991-92. The contribution is in addition to the $700,000 of growers' funds supporting the program. Secondly, the Committee's aim to have the Federal Government match the growers' contribution dollar for dollar has been realised with the introduction of this Rice Levy Bill, and the Rice Research Committee is to be congratulated on this major achievement.

Despite the success of the rice industry in New South Wales, there are several matters of concern to it. One is the instruction given by the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) to the Industry Commission to conduct an inquiry into water resources and waste water disposal. The terms of reference state that the Commission is to report in 12 months on institutional, regulatory or other arrangements subject to influence by governments in Australia which lead to unsustainable and inefficient resource use and advise on how these institutional, regulatory or other arrangements might be revised.

What worries me and irrigators is that this inquiry may be a backdoor way of introducing a resource tax on water, that is, another attempt to increase water charges beyond full cost recovery which it is rumoured the Federal Government has been proposing for some time. I know that the current Treasurer has rejected any such suggestion, and I hope he is speaking on behalf of his Government. However, having read the transcript of a speech he gave to the Canberra Fabian Society when he held the portfolio of Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, all irrigators have some reason to be concerned.

Also of concern is the Federal Industries Commission's inquiry into statutory marketing authorities which was critical of such things as crop acquisition powers. No doubt, the rice industry will be vigilant in this regard, particularly in light of its success in retaining the present marketing arrangements whereby the Rice Marketing Board retains its vesting powers and the ability to authorise the Ricegrowers Cooperative Ltd as its sole buyer.

One misconception that I would like to dispel is that the rice industry is highly protected. Some time ago the Industries Commission calculated the rate of protection for the rice industry at 50 per cent. However, as a result of the Ricegrowers Cooperative Ltd convincing the Industries Commission to use more accurate figures, the level of protection has been revised downwards to 10 per cent. This figure should remove any doubts that the rice industry is highly protected.

I would also like to bring it to the Parliament's attention that the New South Wales rice industry is the only rice industry in the world which is not a recipient of a tariff or any other form of protection. The industry in New South Wales competes successfully with protected industries solely on the basis of industry efficiency, product quality and reliability.

For an intensive irrigation industry, rice is a relatively low user of agricultural chemicals. Very successful quarantine arrangements at the seaboard and around rice growing areas have kept New South Wales free of all exotic rice pests and diseases that are endemic in overseas rice growing areas. However, there is a concern in the industry about the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service's decision to increase the tolerance level for paddy rice contamination in imported milled rice from one grain per kilogram to five grains per kilogram. The New South Wales rice industry is concerned at this decision. Because of the industry's disease-free status, there is no resistance in current rice varieties and no resistant genes in the breeding material. Any action that may threaten this disease-free status is of concern.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would be aware, rural Australia is hurting, but signs for the New South Wales rice industry are more promising than for most other commodities. This can mainly be attributed to the highly efficient management of a New South Wales rice industry by the Ricegrowers Cooperative Ltd. For example, in August 1990 the industry introduced a highly successful production limiting scheme which was strongly supported by growers and which will enable the Ricegrowers Cooperative Ltd to clear its stocks before the 1992 crop harvest. This has placed the rice industry in a strong position in which to manage the potential record crop of up to one million tonnes. A record crop has potential because of the lower returns being experienced by wheat and wool growers and the relatively better situation for rice which will encourage many traditional growers to either reactivate or increase their rice growing areas and encourage some new growers to plant rice for the first time.

Although a record crop will test the receival, storage and milling facilities of the Ricegrowers Cooperative, the returns to growers should be enhanced by the recent reduction in the Californian rice crop due to drought resulting in lower medium grain production, cold weather affecting some European sowings and the serious floods in China should also create some export demand. Without the Russian subsidised fertiliser, production in Vietnam is expected to be lower this year.

I think that, because of the ability of the rice industry to survive and to flourish in times of great difficulty, something should be known of the history of the rice growing industry in Australia. Unfortunately, I believe that my time tonight does not allow me to do this, but I will briefly go through some of the history, particularly of the MIA and the Coleambally irrigation area. Of course, most people would know that John Oxley was a surveyor who first went through the area in 1817. He said that he was the first white man to see it and would, undoubtedly, be the last. He said:
There is a uniformity in the barren desolation of this country that wearies one more than I am able to express.

But today that barren, desolate land makes up the Murrumbidgee and Coleambally irrigation areas which are part of the Riverina and produce one of the world's finest and most sought after rice crops. Rice is grown by nearly 2,500 families in those areas and also the Murray River related irrigation areas and is stored, milled and marketed by their own Ricegrowers Cooperative Ltd. It is rightly regarded as one of the most successful and well-run producers' cooperatives in Australia and this rice growing centre is considered by many experts as the most efficient in the world.

The productive Murrumbidgee irrigation area was born at the turn of the century. By 1913, 3,000 kilometres of canals had been created, harnessing the power of the Murrumbidgee and Murray Rivers. This massive and complicated engineering feat unlocked the resources of these two rivers and provided a huge source of valuable water for agricultural use. However, due to the choice of crops planted by the early pioneers, the Government did not receive the revenue from the irrigation project as it had envisaged.

Fortunately, some rice growing experiments have been conducted during the early stages of settlement in the Riverina. Borrowing from Asia's success with rice production, a variety was planted which had flourished in some of Asia's more tropical highland areas. These early attempts failed and speculation soon grew about the viability of developing a sustainable and profitable rice farming operation in the Riverina.

However, in 1920 one of the region's industry leaders, while visiting California's irrigation project near Sacramento, observed a variety of rice which was thriving in conditions and a climate similar to the Riverina. Convinced that this was the solution to the rice farming problem in Australia--and, indeed, the larger problem of finding a profitable crop to use the costly water--he ordered three bags of seed. In a large-scale trial in 1923 the seed was sown at Leeton and the crop was an overwhelming success. Australia's first commercial rice crop was harvested in 1924 by six farmers who led the way through the early years of this new developing industry and formed the Ricegrowers Association of Australia.

As rice farming in the Riverina flourished, the growers soon realised that they needed a more orderly system for marketing their rice. With more and more farmers choosing to grow rice, many of the important yet tedious marketing functions were being duplicated by each farmer. They knew that if the rice industry in New South Wales was to continue to grow and be profitable they needed to work together in order to create efficient economies of scale.

Through the Ricegrowers Association, the growers lobbied the New South Wales Government and, in 1928, the Government constituted the Marketing of Primary Products Act. In this Act it proclaimed that all rice grown in New South Wales must be delivered to the newly established Rice Marketing Board, that board, of course, being responsible for receiving, drying and storing the paddy, negotiating sale prices, receiving proceeds from sales and returning these proceeds, less costs, to the growers.

From that time, the rice industry has progressed and prospered under very careful management. Of course, in recent times it has come up against other problems. For example, in 1985 a subsidy trade war between the United States and the European Economic Community caused havoc with worldwide rice prices, as it did with other commodity prices. As prices fell, demand for Australian rice plummeted, due to Australia's policy not to artificially lower rice prices with government subsidies. Consequently, the rice industry was forced to take strong measures to cut overhead costs and boost returns to growers.

After great deliberation, the Riverina rice growers decided to rationalise the operations of the industry under the management of one organisation. The new industry organisation, now known as the Ricegrowers Cooperative Ltd, not only allowed for significant cost savings but also generated considerable operating efficiencies. The cooperative now carries out the physical activities which were previously the responsibility of the Rice Marketing Board. This allows for the orderly marketing of all New South Wales grown rice.

The New South Wales rice industry is an efficient industry by any standards, and I have always been impressed by the professionalism displayed by industry leaders. As the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) has just told us, the President of the National Farmers Federation, Graham Blight, was a very active member of the organisation. Of course, Mr Graham Blight is not the only well-known member. There are many respected names in the rice industry which come to mind.

In supporting this Bill I suggest that many other rural commodity organisations could learn from the rice industry, which is not afraid to collectively make tough decisions for its long-term welfare and for those who are economically dependent upon it, while, at the same time, producing a commodity that is equal to the world's best. I commend the Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In the absence of my colleague the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), the shadow Attorney-General, I am leading for the Liberal and National parties in this debate to present our response to the Family Law Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, which seeks to amend the Family Law Act 1975 to fix the maximum retiring age of 70 for Family Court judges. The Liberal and National parties will be supporting the passage of the Bill. We are pleased that the Government has decided to adopt the recommendations of the first report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act. Indeed, an important part of the Liberal and National parties' law and justice policy was fulfilled by the establishment of that Joint Parliamentary Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: In September last year, the honourable member for Kooyong and Senator David Brownhill moved motions in the House and in the Senate to establish the Committee. In December, the Australian Democrats gave their support to the proposal and, in February this year, the Government changed its position and agreed to the establishment of the Joint Parliamentary Select Committee. The Committee is providing an opportunity, for the first time since 1982, for the Parliament to review the family law system. A comprehensive review is currently being conducted and public hearings have commenced.

It is worth while in the context of this debate, although this Bill is a relatively brief one, to remind the House of the terms of reference that the Committee has and the issues that it is to examine. They include: the provision of counselling and mediation services; resolution of custody, guardianship, welfare and access disputes; resolution of property disputes and whether the Act should extend to property disputes arising out of de facto relationships; the enforcement of court orders; the width of discretions conferred upon Family Court judges; the adversarial nature of the proceedings and their associated legal costs; restrictions on the reporting of court proceedings; and the retiring age of Family Court judges.

In its first report, the Committee has examined the retiring age of Family Court judges. It has recommended as a matter of priority that the Family Law Act be amended to fix a maximum retiring age of 70 years for Family Court judges. The Bill before us thus implements the Committee's recommendations. It amends the Act by repealing section 23A, which fixed the maximum retiring age of Family Court judges at 65. The repeal of section 23A means that future appointments to the court will be governed by section 72 of the Constitution, which provides, in its form as amended by a referendum in the late 1970s, a maximum age for Federal Court judges of 70 years. The Bill further amends section 41 of the Act to provide that the Governor-General may make a proclamation under subsection 41(2) in relation to a State Family Court whose judges have a maximum age the same as judges of the Family Court of Australia.

I am pleased to note that the effect of the Bill is in line with the general direction that the Liberal and National parties are taking in their retirement income policies, which provide for raising and, where possible, removing any age bars to the employment of people over 60 and 65 who wish to remain in employment. We are of the view that the national interest makes it essential that our mature and skilled members of the work force be productively employed for as long as possible and for as long as they wish to continue in employment.

In 1977, the retiring age of Family Court judges was set at 65 years of age for a number of reasons. It was thought then that in the family law, more than in other areas, judges adjudicating over disputes should be aware and keep abreast of current social values and attitudes. For this reason and because of the demanding nature of some of the disputes, it was considered appropriate that judges of the Family Court retire at least by the age recognised as the maximum retiring age for most other occupations in the community.

The Committee and the Liberal and National parties are of the view that these reasons are no longer valid. The role of the Family Court judge has been expanded. A Family Court judge no longer deals exclusively with family law, but may now be involved in matters similar to those heard in the Federal Court, where the retiring age is 70 years. The advent of the Commonwealth and State cross-vesting legislation has meant that the Family Court can exercise the jurisdiction of the Federal Court and State Supreme Courts in appropriate matters. Disputes about property in the Family Court can raise complex questions of law relating to property, equity, taxation, contract, company, constitutional and conflict law. Similar questions may be raised in other superior courts where the retiring age is 70.

There will always be concern that judges of any court over the age of 65 may have difficulty in relating to much younger people who appear before them. This is true, I guess, of the way in which many younger people view older people in many other walks of life. But the Liberal and National parties agree with the view expressed by the Committee and the Family Law Council that an important qualification for judges of the court is their awareness of social values. However, there would not be a substantial difference in that area between judges who are 65 and those who are 70 years of age.

Most of the current Family Court judges maintain active family or community lives whilst they are still on the bench and, no doubt, beyond. In any event, there are many other parties who make a significant contribution to the final decision of the judge. There are counsellors and registrars in the court who make reports on how property should be divided up and make recommendations in relation to children in custody disputes. Solicitors, barristers and other witnesses also have an influence on the judge's decision. So

the whole process, although ultimately culminating in the decision of the judge, is a process where there is a large number of experts, professionals and people who have close relationships with the social values, attitudes and needs of people. There is no reason to say that one or any of those on reaching 65 should necessarily then be excluded from continuing in active service in this most vital area of work.

I appreciate that adjudicating on family law matters is a stressful job--and that was one of the reasons that was put forward when the age was set at 65. It is also a highly emotional job and can involve emotional issues. But I note the views of the Chief Justice of the Family Court, the Honourable Justice Nicholson, who queries whether the job of a Family Court judge is necessarily more stressful than that of a judge in any other court or the jobs of many other people who are aged between 65 and 70. I quote from Mr Justice Nicholson's submission to the Committee from whose recommendations this Bill has emanated. His Honour said:

The work of Judges in all such Courts is stressful. There is little to choose between the emotional strain of conducting a criminal trial and arriving at an appropriate sentence, for example, than there is in conducting a trial of a custody or access issue. Matrimonial property disputes frequently require Judges to display the same skills and learning as is required of a Court of Equity.

In any event, this Bill does not require judges to remain on the court past the age of 65 but it enables them to do so. A judge can exercise the right to retire at an earlier age if the work is found to be too stressful or if, for other reasons, the judge decided that his or her career in the service of the Family Court had been complete from his or her point of view. This enables judges to remain and continue to contribute to the age of 75 in lieu of the age of 65, which is the requirement under the present legislation.
I confirm that the Liberal and National parties support the Bill and wish it a speedy passage through this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Again, in the absence of my colleague the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), I present the response to this proposal on behalf of the Liberal and National parties in relation to the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill 1991. This Bill amends the provisions of the National Crime Authority Act 1984. The Liberal and National parties support the general thrust of the Bill. However, during the committee stage I will be moving some amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will make four major changes to the National Crime Authority Act. Firstly, clause 2 of the Bill will insert into the Act proposed new sections 29A and 29B. By these new sections, where the Authority summonses a witness to give oral evidence, or issues a notice requiring the production of documents, a member of the Authority will be given a discretionary power to include in the summons or notice a notation prohibiting the disclosure of certain information.

Secondly, clause 3 of the Bill will amend section 31 of the Act to enable the Authority to apply to a court to obtain a warrant for the arrest of a person who, having been served with a summons, fails or refuses to appear at a hearing conducted by the Authority. The amendment contained in clause 3 is, in effect, one of a clarifying nature for it overcomes the drafting anomaly presently found in section 31(1) of the Act, which empowers the Authority to apply for a warrant of apprehension in the more limited situation where the recipient of a summons is evading service.

Thirdly, clause 4 of the Bill will amend section 50 of the Act to provide that the Chairman of the Authority, instead of the Attorney-General, may appoint counsel to assist the Authority. The delegation of power brought about by clause 4 is an appropriate and reasonable one, for the need to appoint legal counsel to assist the Authority is a matter which the Chairman is in the best position to assess.

Finally, clause 5 of the Bill will amend section 59 of the Act, which sets out the obligation that the Authority has with respect to the provision of reports dealing with the Authority's function. Under the amendment, the Authority, if requested to do so by a State or Territory Minister who is a member of the intergovernmental committee, will be obliged to furnish reports to that Minister about the conduct of the Authority's general investigations in the relevant State or Territory. As I mentioned earlier, when we reach the committee stage, I will move amendments on behalf of the Liberal and National parties which touch upon clause 2 of the Bill which, as I have mentioned, introduces proposed new sections 29A and 29B into the Act.

I take the opportunity now to outline the concerns that we in the Opposition have with these proposed new sections. Under section 28 of the Act, the Authority has power to summons a person to appear before a hearing to give oral evidence and to produce such documents as requested. In addition, section 29 enables the Authority to issue a written notice to a person requiring the person to attend before the Authority and to produce such documents as are requested.

Persons aggrieved by the service of a summons or notice may, pursuant to section 32, ask the Authority to review its decision. If a person is still dissatisfied with the Authority's decision, as reviewed, application may be made to the Federal Court for an order of review. Upon hearing an application the court may affirm or set aside the Authority's decision.

In the past, there have been occasions where persons served with a summons or notice have, perhaps inadvertently, disclosed the existence of the summons or notice and information relating to the Authority's investigations. This, in turn, has had the undesirable consequence of jeopardising investigations conducted by the Authority and has also, in some instances, had the effect of damaging the reputation of other persons. Proposed new sections 29A and 29B are designed to overcome some of these problems. In this respect, the Liberal and National parties welcome this legislative measure as it goes some way towards achieving an appropriate balance between the needs of effective law enforcement and the need to protect the reputation of individuals.

Proposed new section 29A will give the Authority a discretion to include in a summons or notice a notation prohibiting disclosure of relevant information. Under proposed new section 29A(2) the Authority will be able to exercise its discretion only if it is satisfied that a failure to do so might--and I emphasise the word `might'--prejudice the reputation or fair trial of a person or the effectiveness of an investigation or where the failure to include a notation might otherwise be considered to be contrary to the public interest. Proposed new section 29B sets out the circumstances in which a person receiving a summons or notice containing a non-disclosure notation may disclose the existence of such a document and information relevant to it.

We on this side of the House are of the view that the matter can and should be taken further and, to this end, the amendments that we propose contain three elements. Firstly, where it is clear that a failure to include a non-disclosure notation would, as opposed to might, have an adverse effect, the Authority should be under an obligation to include a notation in a summons or notice.

Secondly, if the Authority decides to include a non-disclosure notation in a summons or notice, the Authority should provide a written statement setting out the reasons for the inclusion of the notation and the rights and obligations that the recipient of the summons or notice has.

Thirdly, section 32 of the Act should be amended so that a person who is aggrieved by the receipt of the summons and the terms of the non-disclosure notation may be able to seek an order of review in the Federal Court of Australia.

As the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) will be aware, the Liberal and National parties are and have been supportive of the Authority and believe that the Authority has an important role to play in law enforcement in Australia. In particular, the Authority has a vital function in the collection and dissemination of information and intelligence relating to criminal activities. The Attorney will also be aware that we have been supportive of the new directions being taken by the Authority under its new Chairman, Mr Justice Phillips.

The Liberal and National parties are particularly supportive of the efforts made by His Honour Mr Justice Phillips to enhance cooperation between the Authority and, on the one hand, the Federal Government law enforcement authorities and, on the other hand, State government law enforcement authorities. In the past there has been much duplication and multiplication of effort on the part of various Federal and State law enforcement authorities. It is hoped that the work being done by His Honour will go some way to minimise any unnecessary overlap.

The Liberal and National parties appreciate and acknowledge the efforts being made by Mr Justice Phillips to foster the spirit of openness and cooperation in the Authority's relationship with the parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. The existence of the parliamentary Committee, in acting as a public watchdog, is crucial to ensuring that the Authority is accountable to Parliament and through Parliament to the public. In past years it was a perceived lack of accountability that led to criticisms about the Authority, in particular criticisms that the Authority was overly secretive in its workings. However, in recent times Mr Justice Phillips has helped to build a constructive relationship between the Authority and the parliamentary Committee.

This brings me to two matters on which I seek a response from the Attorney-General. In February of this year Mr Justice Phillips put forward proposals to amend some other provisions of the Act. The proposals, if implemented, would make the Authority's operations more open and accountable. Central to the proposals put forward by His Honour was the need to clarify the statutory relationship between the Authority and the parliamentary Committee. It will be recalled that His Honour proposed that the Act be amended in the following ways: firstly, that the secrecy provisions of the Act be amended so that they have no application to the workings of the Committee; secondly, that greater definition be given to the Committee's powers of inquiry; thirdly, as a corollary to removing the secrecy provisions, that the Committee members be subject to a statutory obligation of confidentiality; fourthly, that the procedures for resolving disputes about the publication of sensitive material be put in place; and, finally, that the Authority be given a discretion to conduct hearings or parts of hearings in public.

In late February the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Kooyong, advised the parliamentary Committee that in principle he supported, with one exception, the proposals put forward by Mr Justice Phillips. My colleague indicated that he had reservations about the proposal for an appointment of a judicial arbiter to resolve disputes between the Committee and the Authority. On 29 May this year the honourable member for Kooyong in this chamber advised the Attorney-General of the Liberal and National parties' support for the legislative reforms proposed by Mr Justice Phillips. Although the proposals are presently before the parliamentary Committee for consideration, I hope that the Attorney-General, on behalf of the Government, is in a position today to express a view as to whether or not the Government supports the changes advocated by His Honour. I ask the Attorney to give an indication today of the Government's thinking in this area. It is disappointing that the proposals put forward by His Honour have not so far been acted on. That disappointment is compounded when one has regard to the fact that legislative action could have been taken by now.

The second matter I raise for the Attorney-General to respond to relates to a proposal put forward by the intergovernmental committee chaired by the Attorney-General to the effect that the parliamentary Joint Committee be abolished. In the debate that took place on 29 May the Attorney-General was advised by the honourable member for Kooyong that the coalition unequivocally opposed this proposal. In response, the Attorney indicated that a meeting would take place in late June--that is, late June last--between the intergovernmental committee and the parliamentary Joint Committee. The Attorney also indicated that the Federal Government's position on the matter would be reviewed after the conclusion of that meeting. Accordingly, I ask the Attorney to inform the House as to the Government's present position on this matter.

In conclusion, the Liberal and National parties hope that the Government will support the amendments that I will move at the committee stage. They also hope that the Attorney, in summing up in this second reading debate, will be able to advise the House of the Government's position with respect to, first, the legislative reforms that the Chairman of the Authority has put forward and, secondly, the future role of the parliamentary Joint Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-At the outset I must say that I appreciate the usual constructive contribution from my colleague the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), but I must disagree with the reasons that he has advanced in anticipation of the amendments that he proposes to move to the provisions of the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill. With respect, he has not adduced any grounds upon which this House could reasonably consider the merits or otherwise of his proposed amendments. In any event, I suggest that the Bill as presently before the House is the legislative framework that has been sought by the National Crime Authority in order to discharge its very important role in the investigation of relevant criminal activity in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Crime Authority Amendment Bill introduces several amendments to the National Crime Authority Act of 1984. These new amendments will be of great assistance to the National Crime Authority in its investigations. The National Crime Authority was established in 1984 and, generally speaking, its focus has been on the investigation of organised crime. For example, the Authority is currently involved in a number of investigations dealing with drug importations, serious offences against the person, large scale tax evasion, money laundering and corporate crime.

The extent of the Authority's investigations has international ramifications. It is in the national interest that the successful conclusion of these investigations will result not only in persons being charged with criminal offences but also in the recovery of substantial funds from either tax evasion or the proceeds of crime. Over recent years the National Crime Authority has recovered millions of dollars as a result of its investigations.

The Authority's 1989-90 annual report notes that assets worth $23.6m were seized under the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 and the Customs Act 1901. Furthermore, as a result of National Crime Authority investigations the Australian Taxation Office collected $8.7m. This is an impressive record.

If the National Crime Authority is to continue its impressive record it must operate under a legislative framework which ensures that its investigatory functions are not impeded or in any way diminished by any deficiencies in the existing Act. For some time, the Authority has recognised that sections 28 and 29 of the Act were deficient.

Under section 28 of the Act a member of the Authority may summon a person to appear at a duly constituted hearing. At the hearing the Authority may make directions prohibiting the disclosure of any evidence before it, including the contents of documents and any information that might lead to the identification of a person who has given or is about to give evidence before the Authority. In practice, summonses issued under section 28 of the Act sometimes contain a notation to the effect that recipients of the summonses must not disclose that they are about to give evidence to the Authority, subject, of course, to their right to obtain legal advice in connection with the matter.

There is conflicting legal opinion as to whether the notation so made on the summons would withstand a challenge in court because the direction contained in the notation was made prior to the hearing. In the case of section 29 of the Act, which enables a member of the Authority to require a person to produce documents for the purposes of the special investigation, there is no provision to ensure that the recipient of the summons is prohibited from disclosing information about the summons.

The amendments in this Bill to section 29 of the Act will allow members of the National Crime Authority to prohibit disclosure of details of or information about summonses or notices issued under sections 28 and 29 of the Act. The notation on summonses, to which I referred earlier, usually contains details about investigations and suspects so as to provide witnesses with information on the matters they will be asked about and documents they will be required to produce. Obviously, their disclosure of these details has the potential to tip off suspects and, more importantly, could threaten the physical safety of witnesses.

The amendment to section 29 will give members of the National Crime Authority discretion to include a notation on process, such as summonses and notices, which will prohibit disclosure of the information in the document, except in any circumstances which the member may specify. This will allow the member of the National Crime Authority to limit the non-disclosure requirements to the particular circumstances of the investigation.

It is important to note that members may include this notation only where they are satisfied that the failure to do so may prejudice the safety, reputation or fair trial of a person or the effectiveness of the investigations or might otherwise be contrary to the public interest. This safeguard provision is in line with the National Crime Authority's desire to be open and accountable.

The amendment also contains a number of other safeguards. First, the non-disclosure notation is automatically cancelled after five years, or sooner than this if the National Crime Authority investigation has been concluded, and all prosecutions that will arise from it have commenced. Secondly, the recipients of National Crime Authority process will always be able to make disclosures in certain circumstances. These circumstances are to obtain legal advice or representation; to obtain legal aid; where a body corporate is served with a National Crime Authority process, such as a summons or a notice, to officers or agents of that body corporate to enable compliance; and if the person served with National Crime Authority process is a legal practitioner, to enable compliance with any legal duty of disclosure which may arise out of the professional relationship with the client, or to enable instructions to be obtained on the waiving of legal professional privilege. Finally, further disclosure can be made in the circumstances, if any, specified in the notation, depending on the particular investigation.

Now that the National Crime Authority has decided to concentrate its investigations on white collar crime, it is in the public interest that the investigations of the Authority remain confidential if the task of the Authority, which is to collect evidence of criminal activity, is to succeed. In respect of section 29 of the Act, it was apparent that because there was not a non-disclosure provision, some institutions, including banks, apparently advised clients that the National Crime Authority was requiring production of their clients' banking records. This had the effect of alerting those persons being investigated, including their associates, to the interest in them by the National Crime Authority. Furthermore, some of the banks, lending institutions or financial institutions took the view that, because there was not a non-disclosure provision contained in section 29 of the Act, the financial institutions therefore had a duty to inform their clients that confidential information relating to their affairs was required by the Authority by force of law.

I understand that the financial institutions also interpreted the legislation as not providing them with any legal protection from a civil suit launched by a client claiming that he or she had not been notified by the bank of the interest in their affairs by the National Crime Authority. This concern by the financial institutions will now be rectified.

It is important to note that members may include a notation, to which I referred earlier, only where they are satisfied that the failure to do so might prejudice the safety, reputation or fair trial of a person. I repeat that because of the comments made by the honourable member for Sturt. Every safeguard has been introduced into these amendments to protect the civil rights of the people who are recipients of National Crime Authority process. The drafting of these amendments is in line with the National Crime Authority's desire to be more open and accountable. Instead of inserting a blanket prohibition into the Act, as could have happened, these provisions will operate when, subject to certain qualifications, a decision is made by a member of the National Crime Authority to restrict disclosure in accordance with the reasons I have advanced in my remarks tonight.

The honourable member for Sturt has already addressed in detail the other amendments proposed in the Bill, particularly with respect to section 31 for the issue of a warrant of arrest of a witness where there is a deficiency of an existing Act; the amendment with respect to counsel assisting the Authority--that is, the deletion of the Attorney-General--and in lieu thereof to enable the Chairman to appoint counsel to assist the Authority; and also the amendment with respect to the furnishing of reports and information, where the amendment authorises the Authority to pass information concerning its general investigations in a State or Territory directly to the relevant Minister who is a member of the intergovernmental committee. In the present situation, only information concerning a specific investigation initiated by a State reference may be provided to the State or Territory Minister.

I record my personal appreciation of the efforts made by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) in his assistance to the Authority and to the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. It is a tribute to his cooperation and careful advice since his assumption of the office of Attorney-General that the Authority in particular and also the parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority have entered a new era of cooperation and constructive reform of the relationship between the Authority and the Joint Committee. I support these Bills and I commend them to the House.
