SPEECH.PARA: The Authority has therefore played a vital part in the fight against major crime in Australia. For example, in its 1989-90 annual report, it was indicated that 79 people had been charged with 650 offences; 38 people were convicted, mostly for offences committed in previous years; assets worth $23.6m were seized under the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 and the Customs Act 1901; $8.7m was collected by the Australian Taxation Office due to NCA activities; and, in addition, some seven kilograms of heroin were seized by officers of the Authority.

It should be recalled, though, in any debate about the NCA that it is not a court of law. The NCA is essentially an investigative body. Thus, section 11 of the National Crime Authority Act 1984 indicates that the primary function of the legislation is:
. . . to collect and analyse criminal information and intelligence relating to relevant criminal activities and to disseminate that information and intelligence. . .

Despite the fact that the NCA is not a court of law, it is surrounded by a number of powers traditionally reserved for courts within our justice system. These powers include: the power to require the attendance of witnesses; the power to allow examination and cross-examination of those witnesses; the power to subpoena documents; and the power to direct that evidence before the Authority not be disclosed. Thus, this Parliament has given the NCA inquisitorial powers. In effect, what we are dealing with here is an exception to the long established and dearly held principles of the British and Australian justice systems that a person is entitled to have all matters of a criminal nature dealt with in a public manner. To repeat an old cliche, justice should not merely be done; it should also be seen to be done.

This Bill will insert provisions into the Act which will enable the NCA to prohibit in certain circumstances the disclosure of, the existence of or any information about summonses or notices issued under the National Crime Authority Act or any proceedings or matters connected with them. As the explanatory memorandum indicates:

The provisions are designed to prevent people whose activities are under investigation by the NCA from becoming aware of the investigation. This has happened in the past when, for example, financial institutions received summonses or notices relating to their clients affairs and felt legally obliged to inform their client. On being told of the receipt of such process, suspects have concealed or destroyed evidence or gone into hiding, thus frustrating NCA investigations. This amendment aims to prevent this happening in the future and clarifies the legal position of bodies such as financial institutions.

The amendment will also ensure that people's safety is not threatened, or their reputation or fair trial is not prejudiced by others revealing the existence of NCA process, or any information about it or proceedings connected with it.
These objectives will achieved by the introduction of proposed new sections 29A and 29B. Section 29(1) of the Act provides:
A member . . . may, by notice in writing served on a person, require the person--
(a) to attend, at a time and place specified in the notice, before a person specified in the notice, being a member of the Authority or a member of the staff of the Authority; and
(b) to produce at that time and place to the person so specified a document or thing specified in the notice, being a document or thing that is relevant to a special investigation.

The proposed new section 29A will allow the member to note on the summons or notice that disclosure of the process is prohibited. Under subsection (2) of proposed new section 29A, the member may include the notation only if satisfied that failure to do so:
(a) might prejudice:
(i) the safety or reputation of the person; or
(ii) the fair trial of a person who has been or may be charged with an offence; or
(iii) the effectiveness of an investigation; or
(b) might otherwise be contrary to the public interest.

I therefore support the amendments which have been foreshadowed by the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), which require the NCA to include a notation where the member is satisfied that a failure to include a notation in a summons or notice would reasonably be expected to prejudice safety, reputation, a fair trial or the effectiveness of the investigation.

I note that section 22 of the Act uses the words `reasonable grounds for suspecting' concerning the issue of search warrants, as does section 24 concerning the delivery to the Authority of a passport. Although the proposed notation acts by way of a warning rather than direct imposition on personal freedom, the consequences of disclosure where there are reasonable grounds to suspect adverse consequences--for individuals, the investigation or the trial--reinforce my view that the notation in those circumstances should be made.

Of more importance is the insertion of a right of review for persons subject to the non-disclosure notation. It is to be noted that the summons or notice is issued by a member of the National Crime Authority, not by a judge or magistrate who would be seen to exercise a degree of impartiality about the matter.

In addition, in the proposed amendment Bill introduced by the Attorney, the notation may be based on the widest of grounds. It is conceivable that many things, of both a major and a minor nature, might prejudice the effectiveness of a National Crime Authority investigation.

And what constitutes public interest? From the perspective of an officer of the National Crime Authority, the public interest may be entirely subsumed by an overwhelming desire to wipe out all crime. While this is an admirable motive, the inquisitorial nature of the process must be balanced against the protection of the fundamental freedoms which our forebears fought hard to establish and to maintain.

A further amendment to section 32 of the Act to make the notation on a summons or notice the subject of an application to the Federal Court would ensure that there is an adequate avenue by which a review of the decision of a member of the NCA may be made in regard to the placing of a notation in the first place. In my submission, such an amendment is consistent with the provisions of section 73 of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987. Section 73 of that Act provides that an application be made to a judge of a Supreme Court for an order directing a financial institution to give information to a law enforcement agency. As a summons or notice under the National Crime Authority Act does not require the order of a judge or even a magistrate, it is reasonable, in my belief, to allow a notation about non-disclosure to be reviewed by a court, in this case by the Federal Court. I therefore support the amendments which have been foreshadowed by the honourable member for Sturt.

Before concluding my remarks and contribution to this debate, I wish to comment on proposed new section 29B. This section creates offences for the disclosure of information where a notation has been made on a summons or notice pursuant to proposed new section 29A and allows for certain exceptions. It is the drafting of the exceptions to non-disclosure with which I have difficulties. I raise this matter for the Attorney, although it is not the subject of any proposed amendments by the honourable member for Sturt.
Proposed new section 29B(2)(e) provides that disclosure of the notice or summons may be made by a legal practitioner:
(i) for the purpose of complying with a legal duty of disclosure arising from his or her professional relationship with a client. . .

Given that the object of the new provision is to prevent people whose activities are under investigation by the NCA from becoming aware of the investigation, it appears to me that a legal practitioner will necessarily be under a legal duty to his client to disclose to that client any demand for documents by the National Crime Authority. If my interpretation is correct, there remains a loophole in the legislation and in the amendment Bill introduced by the Attorney.
In summary and in conclusion, I support the general thrust of this legislation but also support the amendments which have been foreshadowed by the honourable member for Sturt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I support the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill and in doing so make the point that a number of the amendments proposed by the Opposition certainly, at first glance, have substance and will, I am sure, be taken into consideration by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), a Minister who is known to have a fair disposition towards constructive input from our side of the House. I do not propose to canvass the proposed amendments, although the last suggestion raised--that there ought to be a reference to the Federal Court, to a notation, as my colleague the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) might say--does open up the old feeding trough to the legal profession whence the honourable member came, I think. So I suppose he is protecting the interests of his former colleagues. However, it does open up the suggestion, `Here is the trough, stick your noses in it, and add a little more legal cost to the process'. With that observation I caution the Attorney-General in his consideration of the proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: In supporting the legislation, it is appropriate that I take this opportunity to commend Justice Phillips and the National Crime Authority for the successful transition that has taken place during the past 18 months in both the role of the NCA in its relationship with the other criminal investigation authorities in Australia, at State and Federal level, and the role that they play, and also in the style of work being carried through by the Authority. I think it has become evident to people who take an interest in these things that the nature of organised crime, in whatever form it exists, has become much more sophisticated and now involves much more of an emphasis in some ways on the money trail and a more sophisticated analysis, detection and prosecution of those on the money trail than was the case during the first five years of the Authority, when there was very strong evidence that what we would call straight `cops and robbers' criminal activities were much more the focus of attention of the NCA.

It is not easy to manage a transition like that, to adopt more sophisticated approaches, to adopt more sophisticated technology and now to take on probably what will be the most major task of the lot. The proposals incorporated in the legislation go in some way towards assisting the process of prosecution of these more complex modern-day criminal activities. When I say `prosecution', I am obviously aware that the NCA does not have a role in actually prosecuting the persons involved in the activities that it detects. It hands its best briefs over to the Director of Public Prosecutions at State level or, in some cases, at the Federal level and it is then up to those authorities to give weight to the evidence that is brought forward by the NCA and to prosecute those persons through the court system.

I highly commend a recent public seminar held by the NCA, at which the public, along with the media and people who are practising law at all levels, were invited to a three-day exposition in Melbourne. I think the Attorney-General opened that exposition and indicated his support for this process. The courtrooms of Australia are going to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —-The prosecution of complex cases.

—-Yes. The NCA will be the host to some very complex prosecutions. I thank the honourable member for Herbert for giving me some direction as to what I was trying to conceptualise. One of the principal concerns that we all have in relation to those matters is that accused people may not be given a fair trial. They are entitled to a fair trial, and part of that fair trial comes from a proper understanding of the processes. Therefore, it is very important that the media in particular understands the process that will be taking place, understands the complexity of the charges and understands the way different financial networks have been traced. It is also important that juries and, in fact, the Bench understand these complex tracing processes that are now involved in the detection of sophisticated crime. These legislative proposals do include the wherewithal for the NCA to do its job in that form.

SPEECH.PARA: I observed on the front page of today's Sun-Herald some rather strong allegations made by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) in the House last night, in which he expressed his concern that organised crime is, in its various forms, back into the meat processing industry in Australia. I make no comment whatsoever about his claims, other than to say that I share his concerns in this area. I can state before the House that I have seen the very unfortunate situation in which, in my own electorate, a major abattoir employing 400 people was closed in circumstances in which the owners blamed people like the meatworkers and Wally Curran and all the rest of them, whereas in fact it had failed to pay tax instalments to the Australian Taxation Office, it had failed to pay its meat inspection fees and had not passed on to the Taxation Office the tax deductions taken out of workers' wages. For a whole lot of reasons in that particular case the episode came to a halt.

I am also aware that banks have made very large loans to this operation against security which does not exist, and I have to say that I drew some inferences into this whole exercise which are similar to those which have been drawn by the honourable member for Gippsland.

So, while I do not think it helpful for the meat processing industry in Australia to have the whole thing dragged through the coals again, as happened with the meat substitution rackets--(Quorum formed)

I note that now that the House has a quorum, there are about 50 members of the Government in the House and I think three members of the Opposition. I am thankful to my colleagues for coming into the House, and I inform them that I will not be very long.

I was making the comment that I had observed the public comments of the honourable member for Gippsland about his concerns that organised crime had infiltrated the meat industry. I made the observation that I agree with him that it is a matter of concern. This goes to the very heart of what I was talking about earlier. The NCA has gone to enormous lengths to ensure that these issues are properly examined and properly tried in the courtroom process as it evolves. I do not mean the meat issues; I have no idea whether the NCA is investigating or has any interest in that area. The point I make, though, is that the issue is now, rather sensationally, on the front page.

Two problems are associated with that. One is that the meat industry in Australia will certainly suffer, not from the exposure of these things if they are real, but for the same reason that it took nearly a decade to recover from the antics of the spivs associated with the substitution of kangaroo meat and horse meat in export meat. During that time, most of the blame was pointed towards the unions and the workers in the industry. I hope there is not an overreaction to these claims in the judgment of the Australian meat industry. Because of the processes the NCA is now going through to ensure proper education of the key players in the game, I am sure that these matters will be better and more properly examined in the public forums.

I take this opportunity to pay a tribute to my colleague the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay). He is the Chairman of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, which oversees the NCA. He took up that role about 18 months ago in very difficult circumstances. We have now evolved to the point where I believe it can be said that the Committee is working very cooperatively, not only with the NCA but amongst Committee members as well. Interestingly enough, only a few weeks ago we had our first ever meeting with the IGC. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) is to be commended for convincing his State colleagues that there was merit in having discussions with the other body that has the parliamentary responsibility for monitoring the NCA, the Parliamentary Joint Committee. That process is going along well, and the honourable member for Herbert and the Attorney-General should both be given credit for that.

I believe these proposals add significantly to the ability of the NCA to carry out its function. Its function has changed. It is now much more of a coordinator and leading light in the fight against organised crime rather than the solo kind of role it was playing in its early years, albeit for good reason. As I said earlier, the Chairman of the NCA, Justice Phillips, his colleagues and the people working for the NCA deserve considerable credit from this Parliament for the way they have adapted to the very significant change taking place in the role and scope of their organisation. I commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-in reply--In summing up on the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill, I propose to deal with the amendments proposed by the Opposition. Before doing so, however, I should like to pick up on a few general points raised during the debate. It is reasonable to say that something that ran through all the speeches--those of the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) specifically, the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) and, probably by implication, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews), if it was not explicit--was the fact that there is a great deal of support for the efforts of the new Chairman of the NCA, Mr Justice Phillips. That is extremely pleasing to me for two reasons. Firstly, it is very satisfying to see an appointment to the chair of the NCA of somebody like Mr Justice Phillips whom, I must say, I thought was not likely to accept. Secondly, the acceptance of his appointment on both sides of the House showed that there is bipartisanship in some areas, and this was apparent twice tonight in debate.

SPEECH.PARA: One aspect of the work done by Mr Justice Phillips was mentioned by the honourable member for Burke, who referred to the seminar held in Melbourne, under the auspices of the NCA, on complex trials of white collar crime. Sometimes a solution is put forward--in my view, a gross oversimplification--that these trials should be conducted by a specialist court and not by a jury. We would need to be very careful about ever going down that path. The Guinness trial in England showed that one does not have to have a specialist court to hear complex white collar charges. In that trial the jury was given more assistance than usual, even to the extent of having somewhere they could properly take notes; the court was set up in a different way. Looking at something of that nature indicated the change of direction of the NCA, and it was appreciated by all involved.

The honourable member for Herbert and the honourable member for Burke were gracious in their reference to some of the problems that existed between the parliamentary committee, the NCA and, to a large extent, the intergovernmental committee. As the honourable member for Burke said, the honourable member for Herbert came to the position of Chairman of the Committee in difficult circumstances. May I say that he was also pretty difficult, quite correctly, in his defence of his Committee. It was not easy for him, because Committee members had strong views. I will not go back over the matters that concerned the intergovernmental committee; I would rather we put them behind us. I thank the honourable member for Herbert for his efforts in bringing about a lessening of the differences between the IGC and the Joint Parliamentary Committee.

The meeting of the IGC and the Joint Parliamentary Committee started off in a rather strange way. Those honourable members opposite who are members of the Committee will confirm this. I think that people sat there staring at each other for a long while, and it was not all that easy to break the ice. Once the discussion got going it was quite clear that there would be an improvement--I must say, it could not have got much worse--in the relationship between the two bodies. I thank the honourable member for Herbert and all members of the Committee, on both sides of the House, for what was a very constructive meeting.

The honourable member for Sturt raised some specific matters and asked for some answers. They concerned the proposals by Mr Justice Phillips for further amendments to the Act in relation to the Joint Parliamentary Committee. Firstly, he mentioned the secrecy provisions; secondly, greater definition in the area of investigations; thirdly, as a result of the removal of the secrecy provisions, that Committee members be subject to confidentiality; fourthly, the disputes between the two bodies--the Committee and the NCA; fifthly, public hearings; and, finally, and most significantly, the IGC's proposal for the abolition of the Committee. In summary, those were the matters raised by the honourable member for Sturt.

Many of those matters have been overtaken as a result of the first of the meetings between the parliamentary Committee and the IGC. The IGC has not had an opportunity to consider those matters further since that meeting with the Committee, but the intergovernmental committee will be meeting in Melbourne on Friday week, and it is the intention of the Committee to address those proposals.

One other matter that is causing some difficulty is the proposal that we on the IGC put forward--to move towards a judicial arbiter in relation to some matters involving the Committee, and the NCA more specifically. I do not know whether that matter has quite as much support now as it did, but I would not want in any way to pre-empt the thinking of the IGC on Friday week. However, in starting negotiations with what was a very difficult Committee in the sense of the independence of its members on both sides of the House--I will put it no stronger than that --I think the ante was raised when the abolition of the Committee was put forward by the intergovernmental committee. The atmosphere at the time was so bad--this was the view of all the State Attorneys on the intergovernmental committee as well as my own view--that the abolition of the Committee was put forward as a very serious and considered position. I would be very surprised if that matter is pushed any further. It arose, I think, because of all of the matters that I have mentioned. The atmosphere is now different.

In some ways, the fact that it got to that stage was a bit of a lesson to all. I think the responsibilities of the parliamentary Committee, the NCA and the intergovernmental committee are probably now better understood. I do not think that there will be any further attempts to suggest that a parliamentary committee set up to oversee the NCA should be abolished. That matter was touched on to some extent by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews). He said that the NCA was not a court of law--nobody disputes that--but that it has many powers which are normally reserved for a court, and that is why, of course, a parliamentary committee was established. But I think that issue has passed.

In respect of the amendments foreshadowed by the Opposition, I must say that, while I know that the best laid plans sometimes come unstuck, I did not see these amendments until 8.15 this evening and I only had a chance to consider them during the debate. The first amendment proposes the substitution of the word `would' for the word `may' in respect of disclosure. In the short time I have had to look at that amendment, I must say that it does not cause me any particular difficulties. Subject to looking at the drafting and having the necessary discussions, it may be an amendment which does not cause the Government much concern at all; in fact, my immediate disposition is that, subject to procedures which I might indicate in a moment, the amendment is likely to be accepted on this side of the House.

The second amendment is very similar. This amendment requires the reasons for the inclusion of the notation and the written statement of the rights and obligations. At this stage, I think that amendment would also commend itself to the Government, after we have had an opportunity to give it consideration. There is nothing in either of those amendments which, at first glance, causes me any great concern.

I indicate that the third amendment--again, I have not had the opportunity to peruse it in detail; I think the honourable member for Burke mentioned it--does cause me a fair bit of concern, not necessarily for the reasons that the honourable member for Burke put forward. As one who may voluntarily or involuntarily have to return to the legal profession at some stage, I do not propose to join him in his views of it at this stage, other than to say I share his concern that it may lead to a lot of litigation, as has been mentioned by the honourable member for Burke. More significantly than that, though, I think it would create a real difficulty in the NCA's investigations. If it found itself before the Federal Court, it would have to disclose a lot of information about the nature of the case that was currently under investigation. I think that would become extremely complex.

I do not propose to accept the first and second amendments of the Opposition tonight, because I have not had the opportunity to examine them closely in the last half an hour. In respect of the first two amendments, it may be that the matter can be sorted out in the Senate. It would then be very simple for those amendments to come back here. Whilst I cannot agree to them this evening for the reasons that I have put, I do not see any reason why those two amendments could not be accepted at a later stage, and that certainly is my disposition at this stage.

I do have some real difficulties with the third amendment. Once again, I would like an opportunity to have a look at it. I think that the honourable member for Burke and the honourable member for Herbert mentioned that amendment, which does cause us some difficulties. Because the third amendment seeks to insert a new provision in the principal Act rather than amend it, those amendments will not be able to be dealt with together but rather clause by clause. So I have decided that, rather than interrupt the committee stage, it was better to indicate my view on the amendments at this stage. I confirm that, whilst favourably disposed to the first two amendments for the reasons that I have put, I do not propose to accept them tonight. But I think that they will be back here in the not too distant future. In respect of the third amendment, at this stage I find it impossible even to contemplate accepting it, but it is one that I will also have a look at.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 2, page 2, after proposed subsection (2) insert the following subsections:
"`(2A) If the member is satisfied that a failure to include a notation in a summons or notice under this section would reasonably be expected to prejudice:
(a) the safety or reputation of a person; or
(b) the fair trial of a person who has been or may be charged with an offence; or
(c) the effectiveness of an investigation;
the member must include the notation in the summons or notice.
`(2B) If the member includes a notation in the summons or notice, the notation must be accompanied by a written statement setting out:
(a) the reasons for the inclusion of the notation; and
(b) the rights and obligations that the person who was served with, or otherwise given, the summons or notice has under sections 29B and 32.'".

In moving this amendment I will very briefly deal with the comments made by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) in his speech winding up the second reading debate. Firstly, I take the opportunity of thanking him for his responses to the questions I raised. Secondly, in the light of his response, I will not again go through at length the reasons why we have put forward these first two amendments.

I thank the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) for his very kind comment about my speech in the second reading debate. He went on to say that he had difficulty with all the amendments. I emphasise that if these amendments were accepted--and I very much appreciate the Attorney's present response--they would give the National Crime Authority a very wide discretion to determine that one of these notations should be made. This amendment would then put an obligation on the Authority to include such a notation in the circumstances specified in the amendment. The Authority would be required to do that when the circumstances would reasonably be expected to prejudice, firstly, the safety or reputation of a person; secondly, the fair trial of a person who has been or may be charged with an offence; or, thirdly, the effectiveness of the investigations.

I would have thought those grounds would be quite self-explanatory to the honourable member for Herbert. What we are saying is that where the Authority may reasonably expect any of those events to occur--not just in a discretion, because there are wider circumstances in which the Authority may want to use the power that is contained in the Government's amendment to the Bill, but in these special circumstances--it would be obligatory to give people that notification. As implied by the honourable member for Herbert, we are not only concerned about the tip-off situation. Of course, where the tip-off situation is the reason for putting the notation, it should be in the discretion of the Authority. Our concern is as to the manner in which it might affect individuals, as to their safety, their reputation or their fair trial. In circumstances where that can reasonably be expected to occur, even if the Authority is not concerned about the tip-off implications, we think people should be protected by the inclusion of such a notation.

I apologise to the Attorney if my best laid plans did not give him the opportunity of seeing these amendments earlier. I had intended and hoped that the plans put in place would have resulted in him having that opportunity. I appreciate, therefore, his comments as he reads my amendments this evening, and in that context I look forward to us dealing with them in the manner in which the Attorney has described: that they go to the Senate and the Government has more time to consider our proposition. I hope the Government adheres to the view that it has expressed this evening, that it makes any necessary drafting alterations to the achievement of the purposes I have outlined and that we hear from the Senate that these amendments are to be made to the Government's Bill and the necessary procedures are put in place to incorporate proposed clauses 2A and 2B in the Bill.

Clause agreed to.

Applications to Federal Court of Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Hearing Services Bill provides for the establishment of the Hearing Services Authority from 1 July next year. It follows a Cabinet decision in October last year that the National Acoustic Laboratories now become a statutory authority to be known as the Hearing Services Authority. It also repeals the Acoustic Laboratories Act 1948 and amends the National Health Act 1953 to bring the delivery of hearing services under one piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: NAL has been around for a considerable length of time and offers a range of services which broadly fall into three areas: firstly, the research area; secondly, the manufacturing area--either directly or indirectly; and, thirdly, into a service provision area. It provides audiological services, including hearing aids, and in particular hearing aids are presently free of charge under the hearing services program for a range of people, including people under 21 years of age, social security pensioners holding a health benefits card and their dependents, DBA pensioners, members of the armed services, people referred by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service, Commonwealth compensation clients and people referred by Commonwealth medical officers.

There are a whole range of people who, by and large but not exhaustively and completely, are in a disadvantaged group. Certainly the largest number of NAL clients fall into the pensioner group and are, therefore, considered to be somewhat disadvantaged. NAL has in the order of 44 permanent hearing centres and some 65 visiting clinics, all of which are supported by the central laboratory in Chatswood. The central laboratory also undertakes research into hearing loss and evaluates various hearing aids, other audiological equipment and procedures in terms of ways of fitting hearing aids and the like.

Until the recent collaborative arrangement, most of the hearing aids dispensed by NAL had been assembled locally using a case and mechanical parts made in Australia, but using imported electronic components. NAL has until recently purchased most of its hearing aids by tender from various producers and assemblers in Australia made to NAL specifications.

It is interesting to note that until recently at least--and according to these figures I have--the majority of NAL's hearing aids are behind-the-ear hearing aids, whereas most of the aids dispensed by commercial distributors in the private sector--and there are some 31,000 of those--are in-the-ear aids, those that actually bury themselves in the auditory canal and are, therefore, much more discreet. This, in fact, follows a worldwide trend.

The services offered by NAL are indeed very comprehensive and many of its clients develop a very close bond with it. They have complaints about NAL, of course, but they also have some praise. The complaints largely relate to inefficiencies of the service offered. As with many large bureaucracies, NAL has problems in terms of the efficiency of the service offered. There are some complaints about the quality of the hearing aids offered and there has been some criticism of the fact that some of the standards of NAL hearing aids have lagged behind the leading edge of the hearing aid market and certainly behind the quality and the standards of those available in the private sector.

For a number of reasons, the Industry Commission--and prior to that the Industries Assistance Commission, its predecessor--issued some reports on the functions of NAL. The first one was in 1981 when the Industries Assistance Commission issued a report Hearing Aids and Certain Parts Thereof. It found that the Government sector was not subject to market forces and encouraged, therefore, inefficient uses of those resources, resulting in unnecessary costs to consumers and taxpayers. That report was some 10 years ago when, in fact, my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), who is at the table with me, was Minister for Health. The report found that the private sector, taking over NAL's role, would benefit the community in general and the hearing impaired in particular.

There was subsequently a report last year by the Industry Commission which found a number of interesting facts: firstly, that NAL had lagged behind in meeting consumer demand, especially in terms of the in-the-ear hearing aids; secondly, in comparison with commercial private area distributors, it provided an aid which was much less pleasing cosmetically and which was technically inferior; and, thirdly, that it did not offer great flexibility in the provision of services when compared to the private sector.

In its submission to the Industry Commission, the Hearing Aid Council of Australia claimed that commercial distributors updated on a more regular basis and kept pace with new technology, whereas NAL tended to stay with the same technology long after it was outdated. The same council also submitted that, if the private sector had access to the 65 per cent of market which was effectively locked up into NAL, the private sector would be able to realise significant economies of scale and cost and the cost of most private sector fittings could be reduced by about 25 per cent. The Department of Community Services and Health, however, believed that the only problem with NAL was the fluctuation in waiting times which was, in fact, a problem and indeed still is a problem. On the other hand, it offered a very highly regarded service delivery network, particularly with its mobile clinics which went into isolated areas, which many of its clients found to be of great value. The Council also referred to the high degree of competence and skill, particularly in dealing with paediatric cases, which is a very specialised area and requires expert auditory services which NAL claims--and I think with some justification--it can provide in a much better way than the private sector.

There were also a number of submissions in support of NAL in the April draft report. I have a list of sources for those submissions, but I will not go through them here in the interests of time. A number of the submissions were very concerned that changing the structure of NAL in any significant way would have lead to a downgrading of audiological services, particularly to deaf and hearing-impaired children. One claim was that the special expertise of NAL in the paediatric area would have been lost because the private sector lacked that expertise and, particularly, had more expertise in audiometry as opposed to audiology; that is, the fitting of hearing aids rather than the whole question of looking at hearing problems.

There is some truth in that, of course, but it is also true that because NAL has 65 per cent of the market it tends to corner the market in audiologists. There is no reason at all why if, in fact, the fitting of hearing aids, particularly to hearing-impaired children, was farmed out to the private sector, then those audiologists would certainly go to the private sector as well.

There are other concerns, as is always the case with the suggestion of privatisation, which the draft report suggested. It also suggested that the private sector would not have an interest in the provision to the paediatric segment; it would not want to go to isolated areas; and it would not be able to offer the service that NAL provided because it would be cost driven.

The fact that NAL hearing aids are standardised is, of course, both a bonus and a demerit. The advantage, of course, is that it allows for the very rapid servicing and the maintenance of a reasonable stock of spare parts and that that servicing is relatively simple because the staff involved are trained in that one particular type of hearing aid. The disadvantage, of course, is that we get locked into out-of-date technology. That certainly seems to have been the case with NAL to a significant extent. There was also the question of whether the private sector might actually overservice the hearing impaired, although there was no evidence really provided to support such a suggestion.

In the end, the suggestions and the recommendations of the Industry Commission report were: firstly, that all suppliers should be permitted to compete to provide hearing aids under the hearing services program; secondly, that NAL itself should be privatised, separated from the Department of Community Services and Health, as it then was, and funded by payments for the services it provides to hearing services program clients and from revenue generated from sales to those not eligible for such Commonwealth assistance; thirdly, that a schedule of fees should be established to apply for hearing aids and services; fourthly, that the provision of hearing aids and services to children should be restricted to medical practitioners and audiologists; and, fifthly, that full refunds be given for the total cost of hearing aids and services to a variety of children.

The report suggested that tenders should be invited for the provision of non-commercial services, such as visits to schools and to Aboriginal communities, and that the Government in particular should set aside its proposed collaborative arrangement between NAL and the private sector manufacturer. This collaborative arrangement has, indeed, caused some problems. I will come back to that in a moment.

The Bill before us does not alter the availability of services to the clients of NAL, but it does, however, provide for the making of regulations to set charges for hearing services. The Minister, the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples) announced in this year's budget that a $25 annual fee will be imposed to cover the annual supply of batteries, et cetera. The charge is per individual but will apply neither to families in receipt of FAS nor to children of eligible clients.

I think it is fair to point out that the establishment of the authority is central to the collaborative arrangement that I mentioned between NAL and a commercial partner known as Australian Hearing Aids, which is a joint venture between a Swiss consortium and Crystalaid which is, I understand, a wholly owned Australian manufacturing company based in Queensland. The aim of this collaborative arrangement is to design, develop and supply programmable hearing aids in particular to NAL clients. The plan is to develop an export market in Asia, the USA and, indeed, Europe. In the long run, that export market theoretically should be worth something like $9m.

The Industry Commission suggested that the collaborative arrangement should be done away with. It said that there was a range of problems with the proposed arrangement. We also had criticism from a number of the competitors of the partners in the arrangement. For example, Starkey Laboratories (Australia) Pty Ltd, one hearing aid manufacturer which has a very high reputation both locally and overseas, disputed both the value of the anticipated export market and the provision by the collaborative arrangement of low cost, Australian produced hearing aids. Starkey's view was that many hearing aids already on the Australian market are at least equal to, if not more advanced than, the product which the collaborative arrangement hopes to produce--which, of course, is in complete conflict with the statement of the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services at the opening of the joint venture in Queensland on 16 September, when he claimed that the hearing aid program was `in advance of any other type in the world'. That does not seem to be the view of the rest of the industry, but I accept that it may have a slightly more biased point of view there. I am not in a position to make a value judgment on the matter. I simply raise the fact that there have been suggestions that the truth--and the whole truth--has not been entirely told in regard to the quality of the product which is available.

Certainly it is true that there are something like a dozen companies supplying the USA and Europe and, unless the particular product is vastly or significantly superior to those which are already on the market there, it seems unlikely that there will be much scope for further export potential for this new Australian product. There was also, of course, concern about the way in which only selected companies were invited to submit expressions of interest in the tender and the limited amount of time which was available to complete that tender. There have also been some complaints about the proposed legislation from pensioner groups, despite the exemption of FAS recipients and children of NAL clients, who are opposed to the $25 charge.

But we support the Government in this matter. We are always open minded about these things and happy to give a helpful hand. We believe that, with escalating health costs, there is an argument for some type of price signal. I think it is fair to say that the price which individuals would pay if the Commonwealth were not supporting this program would be at least $50 to $100, if one were buying the batteries alone at retail prices, and people would have to pay for maintenance, repairs and the replacement of damaged or lost aids. There are a number of advantages here.

The question is whether we should go further than the proposal to establish a statutory authority and adopt the recommendations of the Industry Commission, which basically are to privatise NAL and do away with the collaborative arrangement. But, as I said, we on this side of the House are an open minded bunch, and we are happy to look at the proposed Hearings Services Authority and give it a chance to work. We believe that a bipartisan approach is appropriate in this situation, so we will not be opposing the recommendations in the Bill. We will support the Government in this matter. We hope that the change to an independent statutory authority and the associated independence from government regulations and the bureaucracy may lead to an improvement in the service. It may lead to an increase in competition. We do have some doubts about the collaborative arrangement, but we are hopeful that our doubts will be unfounded and that NAL will resurrect itself and become a very competitive and viable body in the hearing aid market.

The most important reason for this is, of course, not the Government coffers or, indeed, the coffers of the independent authority, but to make sure that the best quality service is offered to the clients of NAL, in particular to such disadvantaged groups as pensioners and children who are hearing impaired. It is vital that we make sure not only that they are protected and have access to a hearing service but also that they have access to the very best hearing service and the very best hearing aids, to prompt attention to any problems which might arise and, particularly with the children involved, that they have very regular follow-ups. It is very important during the development of children that the fittings, in particular, are altered on a regular basis. This is to make sure that the fittings inside the ear are good, tight fittings; otherwise the hearing aids are unable to function at their optimum level.

They, overwhelmingly, are the most important criteria which the Opposition has followed. We hope that the independent statutory authority will be able to achieve these ends and, for that reason, we will support the legislation. But I take this opportunity to raise a few points which the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has raised and to ask the Minister for comments on those. Firstly, subclause 4(1) defines `hearing products' as including:
(e) such other products as the Minister determines to be hearing products. . .

The Committee considers that this is a Henry VIII clause, which effectively means that the Minister could extend the meaning by way of subordinate legislation. The Committee considers that this is an inappropriate delegation of legislative power as it allows the effects and application of primary legislation to be extended by delegated legislation.

The second problem is with subclause 5(1), which sets out the classes of persons who are to be treated as eligible persons. Again the Minister has the power to determine who comes under this definition and again the Committee considers this to be an inappropriate delegation of legislative power.

The third problem that the Committee has is with subclause 66(5). This imposes a fine for the improper use of the name `NAL' or `National Acoustic Laboratories' or other names as prescribed. Again, the Committee raises the same concern that this may be considered to be an inappropriate delegation of legislative power.

The fourth and last concern which the Senate Standing Committee had was clause 70, which provides that Australian Hearing Services had the power to delegate all or any of its powers to a person. The Committee considers that it may be appropriate to limit the classes of person to whom those powers may be delegated, and the Committee also notes that the explanatory memorandum is misleading in that it assumes that the clause provides that that person is a member of the authority or a member of the staff of the authority when that is not the case.

In summary, we will support this Bill. Our aim in supporting this is to ensure that the very best quality hearing services are offered, in particular to the disadvantaged groups in our society--the pensioners and the hearing impaired young.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I welcome the opportunity to speak to the Hearing Services Bill this evening, as I am sure that many of my constituents will welcome the adoption of this legislation. I also welcome the support that has been provided this evening by the Opposition and I applaud the Opposition's decision to support this Bill in the interests of a better service for hearing impaired people throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill provides for the establishment of the Hearing Services Authority from the start of the next financial year to provide a national scheme for the delivery of hearing rehabilitation and hearing impairment prevention services. The Hearing Services Authority will provide eligible clients with enhanced quality, cost effective, timely and relevant hearing services.

The Bill is beneficial as it does not impact upon the delivery of services to NAL's hearing impaired clients. It simply makes changes to the administrative and operational aspects of the program. NAL will continue to provide hearing rehabilitation services to its traditional clients. There will be no change to eligibility under the new Act. As the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) said, the Authority will continue to provide hearing rehabilitation services to Department of Social Security pensioners with a pensioner health benefits card and their dependants, veterans' affairs pensioners, anyone under the age of 21 years, people referred by the Australian defence forces, Comcare, the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service and the Australian Government Health Service.

In developing this legislation, the Government has reaffirmed its commitment to the hearing impaired in the community. During the term of the Hawke Government, the number of permanently staffed centres has increased to ensure eligible National Acoustic Laboratories clients receive the same level of service wherever they attend a NAL centre. In doing so, the Government has rejected the report of the Industry Commission into the National Acoustic Laboratories. In April last year, when the Industry Commission released its draft report, it recommended that the National Acoustic Laboratories' operations be open ended and that other suppliers be allowed to provide hearing aids under the Federal Government's subsidy scheme.

NAL provides more than 70,000 hearing aids a year. This is more than 65 per cent of all hearing aids distributed in Australia. These people all benefit from the National Acoustic Laboratories. The Government's NAL hearing services program employs a team of highly trained and caring people. These include university trained audiologists, some of whom specialise in either paediatric or adult services, technicians and administrative staff, who all work hard so that eligible clients receive the level of service they require to enable them to communicate effectively in their everyday life. These services are delivered through a network of over 100 permanent and visiting NAL hearing centres to ensure that all clients receive the same level of service across Australia.

Deafness is a problem which confronts many Australians. Each year in Australia, up to 500 babies are born with a significant hearing loss. These children face major disadvantage. Many face a lifelong battle to communicate; many will never achieve a high standard of education; and few have any real chance of a professional career. According to Dr Merv Hyde, a lecturer in education at Griffith University in my electorate, less than one per cent of people with severe hearing impairment reach tertiary education level, and even fewer achieve any kind of professional career. The figure for the hearing section of the population is about 20 per cent.

Last year when the Industry Commission released its report I was contacted by many of my constituents--relatives, families and friends of the hearing impaired, as well as clients of the service--who urged me to lobby the Government not to adopt the recommendations of the Commission. Many times daily I was confronted with stories of how some of the most vulnerable in our community--the aged or those struggling to raise and educate deaf children--would be adversely affected by the changes proposed by the Industry Commission. It is these people, who already face severe disadvantage in our community, who would have been most adversely affected by the changes. They pleaded that they should not be further disadvantaged by the changes that would have been introduced with the adoption of the Commission's report.

It must be pointed out that not one single person contacted me asking that I lobby for the adoption of the Industry Commission report. That is to say, not one person in my electorate wanted the Government to follow the recommendations of the Industry Commission--or no-one was prepared to admit support for such harsh proposals. It is important to note that the clients of the National Acoustic Laboratories (NAL) do not believe that they would be better off with a privatised service. The clients of the National Acoustic Laboratories want a fair and equitable service to which they can have reasonable access.

For the hearing impaired within our community to have a better chance of success means addressing the issue of hearing problems as early as possible and doing as much as possible to reduce the impairment. This was recognised by the Industry Commission in its revised report, which stated:

NAL tests all children referred to it. Urgent cases, usually children with certain `risk factors' apparent after initial screenings by doctors, health clinics, community nurses, etc are given highest priority and are usually seen within a week. The initial assessment procedure for children aged three years or less involves three audiologists, one of whom is a paediatric audiologist. Each child requires an average of 10 hours with audiologists when first diagnosed, then several hours per year thereafter.
This was after the report had earlier noted:

Many participants noted that NAL employs only audiologists, including those who specialise in paediatric work. They argued that the equivalent service is not available outside NAL because most assessment and fitting of hearing aids, in the private sector, is undertaken by audiometrists who have little experience in working with children.

That is the crucial point and the crucial reason why so many people opposed the Industry Commission's report. They realised that they would not receive the same level of service for their children from a privatised service. Many parents who contacted me stated that they were concerned that the private sector would not have the capacity to provide the same comprehensive service as they receive from the audiologists employed by NAL. The report further states:

The Commission accepts that some groups now treated by NAL, in particular children, require specialised treatment. It also notes that many participants praised the quality of services provided to children by NAL audiologists, and expressed scepticism about the private sector's ability to provide a suitable service to this group.

Privatising NAL would mean that hearing impaired children would be further isolated within the community; communication would be even more difficult as they would have great difficulty in accessing quality hearing aids at affordable prices.

What does the Bill before us do? First of all, it replaces several outdated and archaic Acts and combines them into one easily readable piece of legislation. The Bill will establish the Australian Hearing Services Authority to provide services that will include hearing loss assessment, the selection and fitting of appropriate hearing aids and devices, and counselling at no cost to the client. It is only in respect of the repair and maintenance of hearing aids and devices and for the annual supply of batteries that clients other than those in receipt of the family allowance supplement and children of eligible clients will now be required to make a small contribution. The Department of Veterans' Affairs will cover veterans for this cost. I appreciate the support of the Opposition on this point in the legislation.

The reorganisation of NAL as a statutory authority represents just one part of the reforms for the delivery of services to clients who have a hearing impairment and who would not be able to afford the hearing aids and devices supplied by the private sector. Honourable members will be pleased to hear that considerable progress has been made with the joint venture between NAL and its commercial partner, Australian Hearing Aids (AHA). Recently the Minister at the table, the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples), was in Brisbane to open a hearing aid plant in Fortitude Valley. Unfortunately, that is not in my electorate, but it is in the electorate of the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis).

Under collaborative arrangements, NAL will enter into an arrangement with Australian Hearing Aids to develop and produce state-of-the-art hearing products at this plant. AHA will manufacture hearing aids in Australia under a supply contract with the Government. This new facility in Brisbane will manufacture some 70,000 hearing aid units in the first 12 months. By 1994 it is expected to be producing 250,000 hearing aids annually and some 400,000 remote control units. This new plant is good news for Brisbane, good news for Queensland, and good news for the hearing impaired throughout Australia.

Despite what the Industry Commission chooses to believe, National Acoustic Laboratories has achieved international recognition for its research and development activities with a number of recent achievements, and I would like to list them. First is the procedures for prescribing and fitting hearing aids, the first being the Byrne Dillion hearing aid selection slide rule, which has now been computerised and is to be launched and marketed in the United States. Secondly, in regard to hearing conservation, there is the evaluation and testing of hearing protection devices, with the development of a new device that will provide natural protection from high level sounds while not cutting out speech, hence not impeding communication.

A third initiative has been to develop and introduce a new type of radio frequency hearing aid used by NAL clients, particularly benefiting Aboriginal children. A fourth initiative has been the development of procedures for identifying auditory receptive language problems in young children, which enables action to be taken to minimise reading and learning problems. Finally, NAL has made major contributions to relevant Australian and international standards for hearing aids, electro-acoustic and audiometric equipment, hearing conservation, noise and acoustics.

There has been a substantial increase in the number of hearing impaired Australians assisted by NAL over recent years. There has been a 15 per cent increase in the number of applications over the last two years. More timely services are now available to NAL clients, with waiting times now of less than six weeks in 40 per cent of the centres. NAL has also designed and developed FM systems for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders with hearing loss resulting from chronic middle ear infections. Some 250 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children in Queensland alone use NAL FM hearing aids. This service is especially important to these young people, according to Dr Hyde from Griffith University, who states:

In some Aboriginal communities for instance, some 60 percent of the kids have a middle ear disease at any one time and a lot of them have it recurrently month after month. It leaves a terrible legacy in terms of lost learning during those early years at school.

These children, who benefit so much from the National Acoustic Laboratories, will clearly not benefit from the suggestion of privatisation of hearing aid services. Privatisation will hamper even more the process of learning for these children.

The Authority not only will fit and maintain hearing aids but also will research into hearing loss, hearing assessment and rehabilitation, hearing loss prevention and the effects of noise on people. A further activity for the Authority which fits with its more commercial orientation will be the hearing impairment prevention services provided by NAL. These activities fit well with the Government's overall objective of promoting better health in the community. Clearly, the National Acoustic Laboratories provide a complete and comprehensive service for their clients and the changes contained in this legislation will benefit those clients. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The National Acoustic Laboratories have been responsible for the design, the purchase, the distribution and fitting of hearing aids free of charge to hearing impaired people eligible for assistance under the Department of Health, Housing and Community Service's hearing services subprogram. The main clients of this service are holders of pensioner health entitlement cards, persons referred by the Department of Veterans' Affairs, Service personnel and persons under the age of 21 years.

SPEECH.PARA: The services to date have been provided by NAL through 44 permanent hearing centres and 65 visiting clinics. In 1989-90 NAL fitted some 66,700 hearing aids. Outlays for the hearing services program totalled $34.128m in 1990-91 and are estimated to total $53.29m in 1991-92. These outlays, particularly that huge increase, must be seen in the context of the health system generally. There is almost a $10 billion shortfall between the cost of the Medicare system in Australia and the health provided by it and the sum raised by the Medicare levy.

Given the problem generally of scarce resources, the question arises as to what health services we are able to afford as a nation. In these circumstances there is an argument for patient contributions to the cost of the services that are being provided by NAL currently. Indeed, as the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) indicated earlier, it has been estimated that most users of the system would have to pay about $50 to $100 per year for the batteries, the maintenance and the repairs if charged at commercially realistic rates.

It is understandable that the professional providers of hearing services and the pensioner and other groups have been opposed to the user pays principle underlying this Hearing Services Bill. But the annual charge of $25 proposed to be imposed by regulation remains at most a part payment in a health system already costing the nation billions of dollars. What the concerns of these groups point to is the failure of the Government to recognise the increasing demand for resources for the communication impaired. Nearly one in 10 Australians suffers from a hearing impairment, and this ratio leaps to one in three in the age group of 65 years and over. With an increasingly aged population, it is apparent that hearing services must be prepared and equipped to cope with an increase in demand over the rest of this decade. It is tragically true that a communication impairment can happen to anyone--some through birth, some through accidents later in life.

The inability to communicate strikes at the very heart of our humanity. It affects not merely the way in which we are treated but also the way in which we see ourselves. Many well-known people have suffered from various communication disorders. The former Premier of New South Wales, Neville Wran, suffered the paralysis of one of his two vocal chords which had to be treated by injection and which accounts for his rather husky voice. Elton John has small growths or nodules on his vocal chords, which are the lot of the professional singer. Roald Dahl's wife fought her way back from a stroke. King George VI was afflicted with a pronounced stutter that he largely managed to overcome in two years of daily speech therapy after he became king. Winston Churchill and Marilyn Monroe--an unlikely pairing--are also thought to have overcome stutters in their early days. Of course, many of us would have seen the actress Marlee Matlin, who starred in the film Children of a Lesser God, who was born hearing impaired.

In only 20 years time 25 per cent of our population will be over 60 years of age. As our nation ages, our need for the treatment of hearing and communication disorders will become even more urgent than it is already. Ninety-five per cent of people in nursing homes have one or more communication disorders, yet there is only one--one--full time speech pathologist employed in nursing homes throughout Australia. There is no provision for staff in nursing homes to train in and understand how best to communicate with people in their care. Most of the centres and homes which care for people with communication disorders and disabilities do not have regular access to audiologists or speech pathologists, or these services are available only on an irregular or consultancy basis. Only 40 per cent of private hospitals and nursing homes in the private sector receive a consultancy service.

This neglect of the need for speech pathology and related audiology services in our community makes communication impairment the invisible sister in the field of disability. It is much easier to hand out artificial limbs than it is to give ongoing regular or continuous therapy that may last for years. Lack of resources means added stress for both the clients and the professional carers who cannot act on their own diagnosis of what a person may need but, because of budgetary and therefore financial constraints, have to give people only the crumbs of the small cake available rather than what they need. We are talking about giving some people access to the society that the rest of us take for granted; the results are tragic in terms of the loss of human potential.

The cost to government has yet to be appreciated. While 71 per cent of the communication impaired population was identified in a 1986 survey as having an intellectual disability, almost 30 per cent of these people are unable to communicate or have difficulty in communicating but are not in any way intellectually impaired. For these individuals, effective treatment by trained people is the difference between being able to make a life with dignity for themselves and a death-in-life in which their needs, their desires and their interests cannot be expressed or developed.

This Bill again highlights some of the real issues that the Government refuses to face up to about the Australian health system. The Government is willing to introduce a kind of co-payment system here for these services to be provided by the new Australian Hearing Services Authority, but baulks at any realistic assessment of the overall cost of our health system.

Moreover, the views of the Industry Commission have been rejected in this legislation. The Commission concluded that the Government's proposed collaborative arrangement would not be in the community's best interests and should be set aside. In its April 1990 draft report it called the proposed joint venture proposal naive and destined to fail unless it received substantial financial assistance. It concluded by quoting a hearing aid manufacturer which, in its submission to the Commission, stated:

. . . the collaborative arrangement cannot be, will not be of any benefit to anyone except the commercial company. The reason they will benefit is they will be in a position to totally dominate the private sector market. There will be no exports of significance.

The Industry Commission's proposal was that all suppliers should be permitted to compete to provide hearing aids and that the National Acoustic Laboratories should be privatised and separated from the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. They should be funded by payments for the services they provide to hearing services program clients and from the revenue generated from sales to those who are not eligible for Commonwealth assistance.

Here again is the obscenity of the Labor health fantasy: by continuing to subsidise all, including those who can pay for their own health services, Labor's Mad Hatter health policy continues to pretend that the barrel of resources is bottomless, whilst depriving those who ought to be protected of a safety net of its advantages. One can see this demonstrated yet again in this Bill. The eligibility requirements set out in clause 5 not only include those people who hold a card issued by the Commonwealth, known as a pensioner health benefits card, a red service card or a yellow card, to the benefits of which one might expect to be entitled under the provisions of this legislation, but also include a person who is under 21 years of age, a member of the Australian Defence Force and a person who is an officer or employee within the meaning of the Public Service Act.

Here we have a system of positive discrimination towards certain persons arbitrarily chosen by the Minister and the Government to receive these services, when many of these persons--persons under 21 years of age, members of the Australian Defence Force and persons who are employees within the meaning of the Public Service Act--are also entitled to the same provisions and the same benefits as the pensioner receives. The ranking star general in the Australian Defence Force or a senior public servant within the Commonwealth Public Service is, under these provisions, still an eligible person. Here we have what I could only describe as Labor's Mad Hatter health policy being demonstrated again.

At the same time, some of the real concerns of audiologists and speech pathologists are not being met. Will these professionals be represented on the board of the new body? Will there be adequate finance for the research which the Bill predicts, and will adequate standards and properly qualified audiologists be encouraged? Nor does the Bill address some of the more fundamental issues, such as the industrial tyranny which requires a minimum of 21 hours work per week, thus depriving many professional women of a job and clients of professional services because female professionals often wish to work less than the 21 hours per week that is required.

At the end of the day, I reluctantly support the Bill, not because I have any confidence that the proposal will work or achieve the so-called equity which the Government aspires to or much less because the real issues surrounding our health system have been faced, but because changes are required in the overall context of our health system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —-in reply--I thank the honourable members who have contributed to the debate on the Hearing Services Bill. It was quite a nice discussion really, when it got going. I would like to make some comments in response to matters raised, particularly those made by the shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods). He initiated his comments--setting the scene, I suppose--with the usual litany of concerns between public and private enterprise, about large bureaucracies, the markets and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: It is pretty clear that through the National Acoustic Laboratories and the new developments we have a very important process under way that will ensure that Australians get access to not only the best hearing products in the world but also the best services in the world. That is also important. That is as important as the hearing service itself. That is one of the main reasons why the joint venture is now in operation.

Ascom has recognised the virtually unique basis of hearing services in Australia through the National Acoustic Laboratories and the hearing services program, where we have the second largest market in the world. That is not because we have a much higher incidence of hearing impairment, but because we have a national system that ensures that people have access to affordable hearing services. That is achieved in a way which allows not only through the provision of the aid but also through that great network of hearing centres right throughout Australia--both the fixed and the mobile ones which are very much a feature of it--the producer of hearing aids to get access to that consumer feedback that leads to improvements in the quality of the products.

It is interesting that people have gone back to the Industry Commission report. That whole process was very important. It gave many people in the community an opportunity to say what they thought about the structure of the hearing services program and the provision of those services in Australia. It was very clear that the draft report of the Industry Commission changed quite dramatically to its final form. It was forced to realise that through the National Acoustic Laboratories the hearing services program gives great cost efficiency, great service quality to Australia and great industry capacity. That is something that has withstood the rigours of the Industry Commission. It was a very public and exhaustive process.

Comments were also made about out of date technology. Much mention was made of the fact that behind-the-ear hearing aids were old technology and therefore not wanted by people. I put it to the House that about 60 per cent of the market in Europe is behind-the-ear technology. It is not simply and solely the location of the hearing aid but also the quality of the hearing sound that is available to people with different hearing problems. It is becoming more and more clear to people that in Australia we have both behind-the-ear and in-the-ear hearing aids available, particularly through government services, that are equal to the best throughout the world. The best is yet to come, because with the opening up of the new statutory authority and the joint venture we have a great opportunity for Australia not only in terms of export and industry and technology gain but also in terms of access for Australians, young and old, to what is the best in the world in hearing technology.

The concern that I have is that the Opposition, despite its support for this Bill, still seems to harbour the misapprehension that if we split up the market everything would be great--we would get all these wonderful products, there would be great competition and all the rest of it. If the market was opened up, as is suggested, we would be losing one of the great advantages that we have; we would have a loss of economy of scale, which would increase the cost to the taxpayer by about $34m per annum.

One of the problems that we have in Australia is that we are often restricted in our trade and technology by distance, we are restricted by our scale and we are restricted by the fact that often technology seems to leave Australia. Here we have a complete reversal. It is almost the exception that proves the rule. We have a product that does not rely upon very big and efficient distribution systems close to the market. We do not need to have multiple container ships to carry a very big supply of hearing aids. Distance and transport costs are not the problem they would be for a lot of the other products that we sell.

The economy of scale is very important. As the second largest single market of hearing aids under the National Acoustic Laboratories, we have an economy of scale that allows production scaling efficiencies. As I mentioned before, one of the main reasons why we are able to attract the top hearing aid manufacturers in the world to Australia is that we have that consumer network, which is a very big plus and something that feeds back into better quality hearing services.

In this situation, we also have the opportunity to have state of the art, world technology from the Swiss manufacturers being transferred to Australia and the products then being made in Australia to be exported to other parts of the world, particularly to the United States, Japan, eastern Europe and Asia. Therefore, we have a great opportunity which should not be down played. I think we will very quickly learn to be very proud of what we have achieved in this regard. Under the arrangement, Australian Hearing Aids will manufacture the hearing aids from the production facility in Fortitude Valley, as the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) quite proudly announced.
