Once the factory is in full production by 1994, AHA will be producing some 600,000 units, which will include both hearing aids and remote controls. It is estimated that approximately 70 per cent of those units will be for export at a value of around about $25m annually. I think the honourable member for Lowe suggested that the value would be about $9m. I think he was confusing that with the royalties that would be coming to the Government over the period of the contract.

Not only do we have the most sophisticated, world class, programmable hearing aids, but also a purchase price for these units which would certainly be the envy of the world. It is because of the National Acoustic Laboratories, the structure we have had and the structure we will now have that we are able to maintain that price, which is a benefit to the taxpayer and to the consumer and very much a benefit to us when we sell those products on the world market. As I have said on other occasions, it is really a win situation for Australia, the taxpayer, the consumer and certainly our industry.

I will touch on a few points raised by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews). I certainly appreciate many of the things he said. He identified the importance of good hearing and the problems that many people, both young and old, experience when they suffer from hearing loss. Certainly it would be far more difficult to operate in this environment if many honourable members suffered from a hearing impairment, as do so many in our community.

I want to clarify a couple of points for the honourable member's benefit. There has not been a $20m increase in the NAL costs from $29m to $53m. That is incorrect. What has happened is that the extra $20m that seems to have been added to the cost of NAL in the next 12 months is basically money that was previously allocated within the department. So the full cost of the National Acoustic Laboratories has been transferred to the NAL ledger. In fact, in the last 12 months--this will be the case in the future--the National Acoustic Laboratories has contained its costs, reduced waiting times for clients, and has coped with a 15 per cent increase in clients.

In summing up, very few other countries in the world give their citizens the opportunity that has been given to Australians--children, elderly people, veterans and others--over the life of the National Acoustic Laboratories. Not only does it provide the hearing services program, hearing aids and assistance in that regard, but it also performs a very important role in the community by working on the prevention of hearing loss, particularly in industrial environments. About 70 per cent of the products produced in that factory will be exported and will therefore produce a significant and important industry for Australia in that very important area of technology.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wish to explain to the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) and his colleagues all about the better cities program. I can do it very simply in five minutes. The better cities program is a means of bringing together a number of Commonwealth initiatives to address the problems not just of cities but of urban environments and of Australian low density cities. It is part of a series of five different Commonwealth initiatives. The better cities program is a means of bringing together the five initiatives in particular instances for demonstration purposes. Later I will give an example of one possible demonstration project in Brisbane that may well be funded under the better cities program.

SPEECH.PARA: The first of the five initiatives is a national housing strategy. For example, we are looking at the interrelationship between taxation and housing and the efficient supply of land and housing. The second initiative is the housing industry development strategy whereby we look at things such as better skills in the housing industry and new technology, for instance, in medium density housing. The third initiative is the reform of strategic planning; for example, so that we can more accurately identify the demand for and supply of land and housing. The fourth initiative is the reform of the regulatory environment so that, for instance, the regulations which planners use when they impose rules on developers can be simplified. The fifth initiative is the reform of infrastructure charges and taxation, which the Special Premiers Conference is addressing, so that we can look at how State instrumentalities charge for water, electricity and roads, for instance.

The better cities program, which is a fairly modest program of Commonwealth intervention, will bring together in a number of different places each of those five initiatives. The example I have in mind is one based in the inner north-eastern suburbs of Brisbane. It is based on an urban renewal report by the Lord Mayor, Alderman Soorley. The Commonwealth will look at this as an example only if Alderman Soorley can show that all of the five Commonwealth initiatives can be demonstrated as part of this project. He will need to demonstrate that there are the sorts of outcomes that are required.

He must demonstrate that he can reduce the capital and recurrent costs of urban development or redevelopment; that he can make better use of land and infrastructure; that he can increase the housing choice and affordability for people living in that area; that he can improve the links between public transport, employment and services in the area; and that he can reduce traffic congestion and pollution costs and improve access to employment, health, education and community services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Patrick O'Brien, Australia's 1991 Fulbright scholar and a senior visiting fellow at the University of California, asks in the September 1991 issue of Time Australia magazine: `What is wrong with the conduct of politics in Australia?'. He cites the endemic leadership struggles of the last 20 years, the seemingly endless royal commissions and inquiries around Australia, and the way governments and their agencies managed to lose billions of dollars of taxpayers' money in the 1980s.

SPEECH.PARA: The electorate has been asking the same questions and, as a result, an inexorable change is occurring in our system of government. That change is challenging not only the two-party adversary system of politics but also what we call the `Westminster system'. This winner take all model of parliamentary democracy, inherited from Britain, is failing. The concept of a government and opposition arraigned against one another in parliament in two monolithic blocs does not reflect the complexity of society or serve the people's needs. The brutal wielding of the government's majority power in the parliament has destroyed any faith in the myth of parliamentary supremacy.

The executive is supreme and without any real check on its power by parliament. It has proven in too many cases around Australia to be supremely arrogant and corrupt. For a decade, at successive elections at all levels of government and in all States of Australia, the public has been moving to remedy this enormous defect in our system of parliamentary democracy by electing Independents to Parliament. Independents are seen as representatives of their electorates who are not compromised by party executives or preselectors. They are responsible only to the electorate.

Since 1981, when the Australian Senate slipped out of the control of the Executive Government, one by one the various houses of parliament around Australia have done likewise. It is almost incredible that today, out of 15 houses of parliament, we have only four in which the executive still dominates. That situation was unthinkable even three or four years ago.

Supporters of the status quo are, of course, appalled at this trend. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) was reported in the Sunday Telegraph as having said, in effect, `Yes, the system is flawed but there is no alternative'. Laurie Oakes, in the Bulletin of 5 October, under the heading `The Independent Disease', argued without substance that `Independents are useless'.

More perceptive commentators such as Patrick O'Brien take the view that `what is being revealed is that the Westminster system itself is seriously flawed'. The fundamental flaw is the immense power concentration in Premiers, Prime Ministers and executive governments unchecked by parliaments. The unbridled power of the Executive in Queensland, according to O'Brien, confirming the conclusion reached by Commissioner Fitzgerald, `managed to turn parliament into a compliant, powerless--and largely irrelevant--institution that could not even begin to check the power of a government that elevated patronage and secret deals with supporters to an art form'. This power, made possible by the rigid party system and the Constitution, has led to endless destructive leadership fights and the institutionalising of the triumph of the private interest over the public interest. It has led to stacking of the judiciary, government departments, agencies and financial bodies with family, failed candidates, and party acolytes.
